CHARLES SCOTT (City-policeman, 560). I was in Lower Thames-street—there was a crowd, and I saw the prisoner try the pockets of three or four different persons—at last he went to Mrs. Harward, and took out of her pocket this bag and contents—I took it out of his hand, and asked her if it was hers—she said, "Yes"—I asked what it contained—she said four half-crowns and ten shillings, which was so.
Prisoner. I picked it up; I never thieved in my life; the officer said he must have a couple of charges. Witness. I did not—you never stooped.

EDWARD FUNNELL (City-policeman, 32). I was with Scott—I saw the prisoner try two or three women's pockets with his left hand—he then put his left hand into the prosecutrix's pocket, held the pocket with his right hand, and took the bag out—Scott took it from him.

JANE HARWARD
re-examined. This is my bag and money.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1996.
JOHN RAWLINS
stealing 1 cart, value 18l.; the property of
James Patten.

JOHN INSALL . I live in Great Leonard-street, and am in the employ of James Patten, a carman, of 29, Windmill-street, Finsbury—in the afternoon of 30th July, the prisoner came to my master's and said he wanted a brick-fart, to cart some timber from Cannon-street to the Curtain-road for Mr. Rawlins, his uncle, or father—he brought a horse with him, and I allowed him to take one of my master's carts and harness—he did not bring it back—I afterwards saw it in Mr. Austin's, possession—it was worth 18l.

Prisoner. I borrowed it in my own name. Witness. He referred me to Mr. Rawlins, in the Curtain-road—I went there; it turned out to be his uncle—he said he dared to say he would never bring it back again.

GEORGE AUSTIN . I live at Margaret-street, Woolwich. On 31st July, some men came to me, and I went to a yard and saw the prisoner—he said he had got a cart for sale that he had bought at a sale the day before—he

showed it me, and said he wanted 8l. for it—I did not buy it—in the evening, the men came to me and said he had reduced the price—I went to him, and he then asked me 5l. 10s. for it—I said I did not want it, but if he could not get a better customer, I would give him 5l. for it—I was coming away, and he took the 5l.—he was living at a lodging-house, where he had been about six weeks—he borrowed a horse of Mr. Collier—the name of Patten was on the cart, and the word "Lot" was on it—there was something put over the name, and one part of the name on the side was broken off and thrown into the cart—I gave Mr. Patten the cart immediately, till the prisoner was found.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman, R 122). I got the cart from Austin, and delivered it to Mr. Patten—the name on it had been painted over—I rubbed it off, and found Mr. Patten's name on it.
GUILTY .

1997.
JOHN RAWLINS was again indicted
for stealing 1 hand-barrow, value 25s.; the property of
Edward Harper.

MARY ANN HARPER . I am the wife of Edward Harper, a greengrocer, of the Back-road, Kingsland. On 16th Oct., about twelve o'clock, the pri
soner came to my stall—he said, "Is this Ned Harper's stall?"—I said, "Yes"—he said my husband had sent him for the barrow—I gave him the key to go and take it—I afterwards saw him at the station.

JOHN SHEARMAN . On 16th Oct., the prisoner came to me and told me he had truck or barrow to sell—he asked if I would buy it—I said I did not want anything of the kind, but he might bring it—he asked 12s. for it—I bought it for 8s.—he said he wanted to buy a diamond, to go to work, and that would enable him to buy it—I sold the barrow again the same day for 15s.
EDWARD HARPER . This barrow is mine—I never sent the prisoner for it—it is worth about 25s.

WILLIAM HENRY HAIDEN (policeman, N 491). I found the prisoner drunk, at Stoke Newington—I could have brought at least twenty more cases against him.
GUILTY .—
Confined Two Years.

1998.
EDWARD ALLEN and
JAMES MAHONEY
, stealing 2 gallons of brandy, 2 gallons of wine, and 2 bottles, value 3l. 17s. 4d.; the goods of
John Abbott.

MISS ABBOTT. I am the daughter of John Abbott, of the Harrow public-house, High-street, Poplar. We have lost brandy and port wine—we sent for a policeman on 9th of Oct.—I had seen these bottles in the cellar a day or two before—the prisoners were in the place the greater part of the day—they could get from the tap-room to the cellar—these bottles were found in the tap-room—they are my father's.
Mahoney. I was there with four or five men; it is a night-house; there were several girls there drinking; I never was near the cellar.

ELIZA MASTERMAN . I am the wife of William Masterman, of Black Boy-lane, Poplar. On 9th Oct. I saw the prisoners in the long room at the Harrow—I had a quarrel with Mahoney, and he struck me—I went outside and he followed me—he said, "Why do you turn so crabby: come in and have something to drink"—I said I did not want any—he told me to go and ask Allen for something to drink out of that plant—I went, and a man handed a pint of wine to Allen; he drank and gave it me, and told me to drink some, and to drink heartily—Mahoney told me to go and get bottles to put the gin and wine in—Allen said, "It is not down stairs now, it is up
stairs;
I have brought it up here in the tap-room"—I went and told what was done.
Mahoney. Q. Did I tell you any such thing as you have said? A. Yes; you told me to go to Allen for wine, and said you would get two bottles to get some more.
MARY WOODHOUSE . I am the wife of John Woodhouse. Mahoney came to my house and wanted two bottles to put some port wine in; he said it was at old Mr. Abbott's—I would not let him have them.
Mahoney. There were eight or nine men in the tap-room all drinking this, and they said to me, "If you have got a bottle we will give you some."

THOMAS WATKINS (policeman, K 310). I was called in to the tap-room at the Harrow—I found these two stone bottles under the seat in the tap-room—Mahoney was not more than a foot from them; Allen was not there—I left them in the bar, and took Mahoney.

JOSEPH LOCKETT (policeman, K 177). I took Allen; I told him the charge—he said he knew nothing about it; he was innocent—in going to the station he said, "If I get out again I will do for you"—he tried to throw me; my thumb is out of joint now.

Aliens Defence. I had been out all night at a wake; I came in the public-house and saw some persons drinking; I saw the bottles, but do not know what was in them.
NOT GUILTY .

1999.
WILLIAM ROUSE
, stealing 1 shilling and 2 sixpences; the money of
George Anscomb: having been before convicted.

ANN ANSCOMB . I am the wife of George Anscomb, of Hoxton, and keep a tripe-shop. On 12th Oct., about eleven in the forenoon, I went to the parlour window, and saw the prisoner's hand in the till—I shut the shop door and shut him in—he requested I would not do anything with him; if it were half a crown or five shillings be would make it up to me if I would not do anything—I gave him in charge, went to the till, and missed 1s.—the prisoner put something in his mouth—I said, "You are swallowing some
thing"—he never spoke for about a minute; he then said, "No, I have not, but for God's sake forgive me this time: I will never do it any more. "

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When had you seen the till? A. I was there within five minutes of the time—there had been no customer in—I went to the till when the policeman came—I did not say, "There is all the halfpence here"—I did not put any silver from my pocket; I had none in it—I said at the time I could not swear whether it was a shilling or eighteen pence I missed; I could not call to my mind what I had paid away—while I was shutting the door I turned my back on him, but still I had my eye on him—he moved more towards the corner of the shop—he turned his head another way to swallow it—a person in the shop said, "He is swallowing something."
WILLIAM GROOMBRIDOE (policeman, N 203). The prisoner was given in my custody on 12th Oct.—I searched him, and found only one halfpenny.

JOHN KAVENY (police-sergeant, N 26). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction—(read—Convicted Dec. 1848, and confined six months)—he is the person.
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined One Year ,

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Ald. SIDNEY; Mr. Ald, FINNIS; Mr. Ald. CARDEN, and

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq. and the Third Jury.

div1.p:
2000.
CATHERINE KEIM , was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months.

2001.
MARK ISAACS
, unlawfully assaulting
John Coursay.
NOT GUILTY .

2002.
JOHN PRESTON
, unlawfully assaulting
William Martin, on the high seas.

WILLIAM MARTIN . I was an apprentice on board the bark Atlantic, of which the prisoner was chief mate. I joined her on 11th Sept., 1848; she was bound for the North of England first, and then we went to Naples and Malta; from there to Messina, Constantinople, and Odessa, we touched at Gibraltar on our way home, and arrived in England at the beginning of this month—I believe we got into Naples harbour, at the latter part of last Nov.; while there the prisoner ordered me to fill a cistern; while doing so, he came to me and asked why I did not fill it before—I said, "I had something else to do, and he took me by the left ear and swung me down on to the deck, and my ear has been swollen ever since; and I have lost the hearing of that side altogether—whilst at Malta, in March, I was keeping watch, and went to call one of my fellow-apprentices—when I came up, the prisoner said I had been sleeping below—I said, "I had not; I had mistaken the time; I had been to call the other apprentice," and he said, "I have caught you at last, you d—d young fellow," and took a handspike from the windlass, and gave me a blow on the arm with it; my arm fell down powerless, and it left like pins and needles in my arm, and I fell down on the cable chain on my face—my face nose and eyes bled profusely, and my eyes were black for two or three days afterwards—about the middle of Aug. we were at Gibraltar, I was drawing up a bucket of water, the prisoner came and took the bucket from me as my fellow-apprentice was in the act of taking it from me, and he struck me in the back of the neck with it, which knocked me down—I fell on the deck, and caught my head and face on the edge of a large water-cask, which broke the bridge of my nose—the bucket was made of canvass—there was no medical man on board, and never had been—when we got to London, I had liberty from the captain on 7th Oct. to go on shore—I told the mate I was going, and he said I should not—I remained on board till the 9th, when constable Frazer came and took me to the Thames police-office—I afterwards went to Mr. Ross, and showed him my injuries.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. A. What did you say the bucket was made of? A. Canvass—I once fell from the mizen-mast, about two feet from the deck, and caught my hip; I think that was in the Black Sea—the vessel was at Malta a month or six weeks, in harbour—I did not then mention to the captain that the mate had struck me—I was afraid of the prisoner—he said he would break my head and throw me overboard—no surgeon attended me till I came home—I mentioned it to the captain, and showed him my arm a fortnight before we came to Falmouth; that was the second time I had

mentioned it—I helped to put in the stones as well as I could at Constan-tinople, and also at Malta—that was after my arm was broken—they were heavy stones, two feet wide—they were slid down a plank, and sometimes I had to lift them with both hands—the captain looked over us while we were doing it—there were six men helping, besides the apprentices—no one set my arm or put splints to it; it joined together again by itself—I continued working as well as I could—the prisoner often complained to the captain of my being lazy and dirty, and the captain often spoke to me about it—when he took me by the ear at Naples, he was not bringing me to the captain to complain of me—I had to do something else when he ordered me to fill the cistern—I was to receive my orders from him—I never had anything the matter with my ear before—it was as sound as the other is—at the time he hurt my ear, the captain was walking on the quarter-deck, and saw it all, and reprimanded him for doing it—you might say he was pulling me towards the captain, but he said nothing to him—I cried out when I fell down—complaints were made to the captain about my filthiness and laziness every week—the captain did not give me any money or clothes—the clothes I had when I came ashore were given me by the sailors.

MR. PARNELL. Q. Was it your first voyage? A. Yes; the stones were being taken out of our vessel and put into a lighter—I was in the lighter, and they were slid down a slanting-plank, at the top of which the mate was, and he pushed them down so that they took a piece right out of my hand—they came down so fast that I could not stop them, and my hand was jammed between two of them—it bled, and I bandaged it up with one of my collars—two of the seamen are here who saw it—when we got to London the seamen and the other apprentices were allowed to go ashore.

JOHN MARTIN . I am the last witness's brother, and am a commercial traveller—I shipped my brother, about thirteen months ago, on board the Atlantic—he was then in good health, and his limbs were sound—his arm was not in the least broken, and he had the use of both ears—he now speaks terribly through his nose, quite different to what he did—I found him in a most deplorable condition in every way when he came on shore.

CHARLES FRASER (Thames-policeman, 73). In consequence of information, about 9th Oct. I went on board the Atlantic, and saw the prisoner—I asked him if he had a person named Martin on board—he said, "You mean Nosey"—I said, "I do not know anything about Nosey"—he said he would show him to me—he called him up out of the hold, and I asked him, in the pri
soner's presence, what was the matter with him—I said, "Have you been ill-used?"—he said, "Yes, I have; "and said he had got his nose and arm broken—I said, "Why did not you go to the Magistrate? why did not you go on shore?"—the mate said the master has forbad him going on shore—I took him to the station, and afterwards to the Magistrate, who gave a summons against the prisoner, and I took him—I afterwards took Martin to Mr. Ross, the surgeon.
Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner brought him up to you when you asked for him? A. Yes; he said the captain had given strict orders that no one was to go OD shore out of the ship.

DANIEL Ross. I am a surgeon, at Shadwell. I examined Martin, and found the bone of the left arm had been broken, and the bones of the nose, and there was a slight enlargement of the left ear—such treatment as he has spoken of, might be sufficient to cause deafness—he appears to be deaf with the left ear.
Cross-examined. Q. The appearance of the ear would not enable you to

attribute the deafness to the treatment he received? A. No; I examined the internal part of his ear—the cause of deafness was probably some injury to the drum of the ear, cold, or anything of that kind—a fall from the mast might break the nose—his arm was broken rather higher than the middle—it has firmly united, the higher bone slightly over-lapping—it had been actually broken.
MR. PARNELL. Q. Did it appear to be self-set? A. It had united very well; nature would do that by keeping it at rest.

PETER INGLIS . I am a sailor; I joined the Atlantic at Malta, and went to Constantinople and Odessa. I know Martin and the defendant—I recollect Martin telling us at Malta of the injury to his arm—I was not present when it was received—I was at work at the stones at Constantinople—I staid with the vessel till she came to London—I recollect Martin sustaining an injury to his face and nose at Gibraltar—that was about 20th Aug.—I saw him about a minute after—I had seen him without the injuries three minutes before—I was on the opposite side of the ship, and could not see where he was—I heard him sing out just after he was knocked down—I had seen the mate about two minutes before, and he went towards where the boys were pumping the ship out.

Cross-examined. Q. Had the mate occasion to complain of you? A. Not that I know of—the captain did speak to me several times, in consequence of what the mate told him—he spoke to me about taking the boy's part when the mate ill-used him—he told me I had better be quiet and not trouble my head about it—the captain spoke to me about sticking up for my rights and telling the other men to stick up for their rights—there were five boys and nine men on board.

EDWIN PILL . I am a seaman; I joined the Atlantic at Malta, and con
tinued with her till she got to London I was present when the stones were unloaded at Constantinople—from there we sailed to Gibraltar—I saw the injury to Martin's nose after it was done, I was on shore at the time—when I came back to the vessel his nose was black, and bled very much—I saw the mate on board—the boy told me how it was done—the mate was not then present.
Cross-examined. Q. Was the skin off at all? A. Yes—that is a very unusual thing with sailors—I never received any injury.
MR. PARNELL. Q. The mate never attempted to break your nose? A. Yes, he did once.

JOHN LEONARD . I am captain of the vessel. Martin never told me anything about the injury to his arm till a fortnight before we got to Falmouth—he then said he would have the mate up about it—the mate denied breaking his arm, and said he knew nothing about it—I saw the injury to his ear some time after he was at Naples; the lower part of it looked swelled and rather sore—I asked the mate if he had acted so brutally as to injure him—he said he was shoving him along to his work, and he fell on the chain and hurt his ear—we left Malta about 15th March, and returned on 19th—after we left Gibraltar the mate admitted the injuries to the boy's ear and nose—he said, "The boy aggravated me and dared me to it; that I could not govern my passion"—I gave the boy leave to go ashore.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe he had been troublesome during the voyage? A. Very indolent, and very dirty; the mate had complained to me of his insolence—I saw him at Malta on the 9th—he had to lift flag-stones of 50 or 60 lbs. each, breast-high, from a boat to the shore, and I had not the slightest impression anything was the matter—I beard nothing about his arm

till about a fortnight before we arrived at Falmouth—I know he had two fells, one of about two feet perpendicular, and the other ten or twelve feet, but do not think his arm could have been broken on either of those occasions, as he never complained to me of it—I did hear him say, about 8th Jan., that the mate struck him with a canvass bucket of water—the mate complained of the trouble he had with the boy, and I said, "Let him do what he can; it is of no use to abuse or beat him, for it will do no good."

MR. PARNELL. Q. How long after you left Malta were the stones brought on board? A. The last were on 9th March, when the boy fell—we were on the homeward passage, about a month before we got to Gibraltar—we had a sixty-days' passage, and arrived in London in Oct.—we were at Gibraltar Bar in the beginning of Aug., and I should think one fall was at least a month before that, and the first about a week earlier—it was between Con
stantinople and Gibraltar—the boy is a native of Scotland, brought up at New Brunswick—he was shipped last October.

MR. ROSS re-examined. I am unable to say how old the fracture of the arm is—I should say it has been done more than three months; it might be six—it is impossible that he could lift a stone of half a cwt, with it.
GUILTY .

2003.
JOHN PRESTON was again indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
John Brennan on the high seas: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Three Weeks.

2004.
BENJAMIN HENRY MAYERS and
WILLIAM CHARLES HITCHIN
, unlawfully conspiring to obtain goods from
Robert Peacock Gloag, with intent to defraud him.
NOT GUILTY .

2005.
JANE SINCLAIR was indicted
for a conspiracy.

MR. ROBINSON conducted the Prosecution WILLIAM VINCENT. I am assistant to Mr. Joseph Avant, of Fleet-street. On 22d Aug., the prisoner came to his shop, laid this ring (produced) on the counter, and asked 1l. on it—I heard my fellow-shopman ask her if it was gold; she said it was—I offered 15s. on it—she said that was not sufficient, and went out to inquire if it was—she returned in ten minutes, and said that would answer the purpose, and I gave her 15s.

JOHN FREDERICK SIMONS . I am in the service of Mr. Clark, of 55, Long-acre. On 29th Aug., about six o'cloek, the prisoner came and offered me a ring in pledge, very similar to the one produced—I cannot say whether she asked 1l. or 25s. on it—I asked if it was gold—she said it was—I told her I had seen her before, and also a ring of that description, and one had been taken at our house very similar to it—I said it was brought by a man—I can undertake to swear they were manufactured by the same person—this is the one (produced)—I told her I should take it to a refiner—he notched it, and applied the test, and I came back and told her if she offered it at any other shop she would be committing a fraud—I showed her the notch, and applied other tests, which I showed her—she became violent, and said I was not obliged to take it without I liked—she insisted on having it back, and at last I gave it her—she then left the shop, and I gave directions to Saxby.

ARTHUR SAXBY . I am also in Mr. Clark's service. On 29th Aug. I received instructions from Simons; in consequence of which, I followed the prisoner into a public-house in Mercer-street—she waited there twenty minutes or half an hour; she then came out, and went towards Leicester-square,

where she was joined by a man, and they went into King William-street, walked about there half an hour, then turned into St. Martin's-lane, and the prisoner went into a pawnbroker's shop—the man waited on the oppo
site side—I went into the front shop, and told a young man there that there was a duffer in one of the boxes—the prisoner could not see me—I saw her pass a ring along the counter similar to these—she was asked if it was gold—she said, "Yes"—the man filed and tried it with the test, and gave it her back—I did not hear him say anything about it—she could not see him file or try it—she then took the ring, left the shop, walked up St. Martin's-lane, and was joined by the man—they then went into Broad-street, Bloomsbury—the prisoner went into Mrs. Wood's shop, and the man waited at the corner of the street—I went into the shop, and made a communication to the shop-man—I saw a ring offered to the shopman—he asked if it was gold; she said it was—he tried it with a file and the acid—I think she might have seen him do that—he then gave it her back—I did not hear him say anything—when she got outside, she joined the man, and they went to a pawnbroker's at the corner of Wells-street—the prisoner went in, and the man waited on the opposite side—I went into the shop, and made a communication—the prisoner tendered the ring in the same way—the shopman tried it, gave it her back, and told her she was a duffer, and if she came there any more he would give her into custody—she said, "Why don't you do it now?"—she then left the shop—I did not then see the man—the prisoner then went into the boxes at Mr. Webb's—I went in, and saw a ring offered there; it was the same ring as far as I could judge.

HENRY EMBLEM . I am assistant to Dobree and Tomlinson, pawnbrokers, in the Strand. On.31st Aug. the prisoner came and offered this ring (produced)—I asked her if it was gold—she said, "Yes"—I asked her what she wanted—she said, 1l., and I lent her 17s.—she gave her name," Jane Russell, 7, Edgware-road"—I have examined the ring with the one produced by Vincent, and they precisely correspond—I should say they were made by the same person.

GEORGE WEBB. I am a pawnbroker, of 207, Holborn. On 29th Aug. the prisoner came into the boxes at our shop—Saxby came in, and made a communication—the prisoner offered a ring similar to these produced—I asked her if it was gold—she said, "Yes"—there were four or five notches in it—I tested it, told her it was not gold, and gave it her back—she went away—on 14th Sept. she called again, and offered me this ring (produced by Miller)—I asked if it was gold—she said, "You ought to know better than me"—I asked her where she got it from—she said her husband gave two sovereigns for it—I asked what she wanted on it—she said, 12s.—I said I should detain it—I told her to send her husband—she said he was in the country—she wanted the ring back, and I told her I should give her into custody—I sent for a policeman, and she was given into custody—2s. 6d. is the utmost value of the ring—two rings were pawned with me in 1848 of the same make as these, but not precisely of the same pattern—this one (produced) was pawned in Aug., 1848—rings are manufactured like these in India—they are meant to wear on the finger.

ELIZA JONES . I am a widow, and live at 18, Fashion-street, Spitalfields. The prisoner lodged with me, on and off, for five years, always as a single woman—a man visited her a few times, but never came further than the door—I have not seen him lately—she never said anything to me about him, or any other man—she said she went out selling an article for a man, getting a better price than he could get; she did not say what man.

WILLIAM MILLER (policeman, F 80). On 14th Sept. the prisoner was given into my custody by Mr. Webb's assistant, with this ring, which I have produced—I gave it to Mr. Johnson, who assayed it, and gave it me sealed up.
SUTCLIFFE. I am an assistant to my brother, who is a refiner.
Mr. Clark's assistant brought me a ring; it was metal inside, cased with gold, and worth 4s. or 5s.

JOHNSON. I am an assay-master. I assayed one ring about the 10th;part of it was gold, and worth about 10s. an ounce—I did not weigh it, and cannot tell how much it was worth—it was under half an ounce—I have no doubt, from their appearance, that these rings are all of the same character—(The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was here read—"I always thought the ring was gold, my husband used to tell me so—my husband has been dead two years—the reason I went to the pawnbroker's after I had been cautioned was, because I wanted money.")

Prisoner's Defence. I did not mean to do any injury to the parties; I do not know the manufacturer of the rings; if they do not prove to be gold I cannot help it.
GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2006.
ROBERT YORSTON
, unlawfully obtaining money of
John Winston by false pretences.

JOHN WINSTON . I live on my property, and reside at 84, Waterloo-road. About 22d Sept. my son was in custody on some criminal charge—on that evening I met the prisoner at Mr. Butcher's shop, in the Waterloo-road—I told him my son had unfortunately got into trouble—he said, "Well, what is it?"—I told him I understood it was for stealing a looking-glass, and I believed it was at the West-end—he said, anything he could do for me he would—I said, "I have known you some time as an attorney, I suppose you are an attorney?"—he said, "Yes, I am, living at 10, Clifford's-inn"—he said nothing about being a clerk to Mr. Townshend—I never heard that name till I was at the Police-court, when the prisoner was there on this charge—I said I was very much inclined not to do anything for my son, but for the sake of my own conscience I must employ one of you gentlemen (the Counsel), and I asked him what money he wanted—he said 1l. 3s. 6d. or not exceeding 25s. for the present—he said there would be 1l. 1s. for the counsel, and 2s. 6d. for the clerk's fee—it was afterwards decided that he was to have 25s., and he was to meet me at Mr. Butcher's the next afternoon, when he was to make out a brief—I did not meet him the next day, I was very ill of the cholera, and was advised to go into the country till the trial was over—I went to Mr. Butcher, told him to let the prisoner have 23s. 6d. or 25s., whichever he wanted, and I went into the country—Mr. Butcher did not owe me any money—I returned on the evening of 25th, the day the trial took place—I knew the trial would come on that day—I called on Mr. Butcher that evening, to inquire what my son was done to—Mr. Butcher told me he had got twelve months, and produced this letter to me—(read—" 10, Clifford's-inn, Tuesday afternoon. Dear Butcher, I wrote yesterday to Mr. Palmer, and gave him all to-morrow (Wednesday) to pay the bill, and 5s. expenses. Will you tell Mr. Vincent his son was tried in the name of John George, and was got off with only twelve months—what think you of that? Yours truly, R. Yorston")—I called on Mr. Butcher again the next morning, and asked Him if he had paid the sum—he said, "Yes, I have, and here is the receipt for the money from Yorston," and he produced this paper (produced)—(read—"24th Sept. 1849. Memorandum. Mr. Butcher has paid me 1l. 5s. for Mr. Vincent, to pay the fee to counsel to defend Mr. Vincent, jun. on his

trial at the Central Criminal Court. For C. Townshend. R. Yorston")—I repaid Mr. Butcher the money, and went to 10, Clifford's-inn, asked for the prisoner, and he was not at home—I went a second time, and he was not at home—I then found out that my son had not been defended, and was told that Mr. Meller had defended the others who were tried with him; and I went to Mr. Meller's office—on 7th Oct. I went to 10, Clifford's-inn, with a policeman, and saw the prisoner—that was the first time I had seen him since the 22d Sept.—he ordered me out of the place—I said to the policeman, who was with me, "This is the person; I give this man in charge"—when he told me he was an attorney I believed him, or I should not have given him the money—I had known him to do business for Mr. Butcher for about ten months, and saw him with papers tied up with red tape, and he was always talking of law—he said nothing on 22d about being clerk to an attorney.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Are you a gentleman? A. No; I have just got enough to find myself a bit of bread; what you call a poor gentleman—I have been a private in the army—my son did not collect my rents—he has robbed me of hundreds of pounds, but I never charged him—I have known Mr. Yorston nine or ten months, and seen him occasionally—I never before had occasion to ask him if he was an attorney—I thought I would ask him when my child was likely to be sent out of the country—he had been convicted before, and was taken up a very few days after he came out of gaol.

MR. M'MAHON. Q. When your son was about to be transported, you were particular in asking the question? A. I asked whether he was an attorney, because I would not have it said, after my son was gone, that I had not done my duty.

JAMES BUTCHER . I live at 117. Waterloo-road, and know the prisoner and Mr. Winston. Mr. Winston came to my shop on Sunday, 23d Sept., and asked me to give Yorston 25s. to ask for a mitigation of the punishment of his son—they had been talking about it in my shop on the evening before—Yorston came on Monday, 24th—I gave him 25s., and he gave me the receipt, which has been produced—I do not recollect whether I showed that to Mr. Winston—I did show him the letter—the name in the receipt is Vincent, but we call him Winston—I told Yorston he was to go to Clerken-well, and find a policeman, whose number and letter I told him, and he would tell him all about it—I did not tell him where the trial was to take place—he said he had a cause to attend at the Insolvent Debtors' Court, and he would attend to this if he possibly could—on the Tuesday evening I received the letter from him which has been read—the prosecutor called on me on the Tuesday evening, and again on Wednesday morning—I gave him the receipt and he paid me the 25s.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. About three years—I have employed his master, Mr. Townshend—I knew perfectly well that he was an attorney's clerk—I believe that was generally known—I cannot say whether Mr. Winston knew it—I think Winston has been in the house when the prisoner and I have talked about my business with Mr. Townshend, but he walked away when we talked about business—I do not recollect Mr. Winston saying he thought the man might have said he was an attorney's clerk—I am quite sure the prisoner was clerk to Mr. Townshend at that time.

WILLIAM COOMBES (policeman, L 94). On 25th Sept. I was at Clerken
well Sessions, and saw three persons tried in the name of John George. Fisher, and Garrod—George was not defended by counsel, the others were—I

afterwards took the prisoner into custody, and told him it was for obtaining 25s. from Mr. Winston under false pretences—he resisted, and said I could not take him out of the City, and said, "If I give you the 25s. will you give it to Mr. Winston?"—I said, "No, I am a constable, not a compromiser"—he said, "All I know about it is I found the case was over and pocketed the money"—he said nothing about the Sessions.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you any warrant? A. No—I was in plain clothes—I showed him my warrant-card as a policeman.

HENRY JAMES MELLER, ESQ . I am a barrister, of the Middle Temple, and occupy chambers at 4, Brick-court. On 25th Sept. I attended the Middlesex Session professionally, and defended two men named Fisher and Garrod—there was a third, of the name of George, who I did not defend—I was not instructed to do so—I had received some communication from my clerk, who is here, but I did not defend him.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know that the prisoner is clerk to Mr. Townshend, in Clifford's-inn? A. I believe he is—I believe he lives in the Inn—up to this time I have always considered him a decent respectable man—I saw him in Court about an hour after the men had been tried—they were all convicted—it was a very bad case, especially as it regarded George—it is a matter of opinion whether George was in good luck, to get off with twelve months, being known before.

JOHN BROOKS . I am clerk to Mr. Meller. On Tuesday morning, 25th Sept., the prisoner spoke to me—he did not give me a brief, or any instruc
tions to defend a man of the name of George.

Cross-examined. Q. He said he had something to do with a young man, but he did not know his name? A. He said it was something with regard to a young man with two others for stealing a looking-glass, but he did not know the name.

ROBERT HALL . I am a clerk in the Register-office of Attorneys. I have examined the roll of attorneys at the office of the Incorporated Law Society in Chancery-lane—I do not find the prisoner's name there as an attorney—Mr. James, the solicitor for the prosecution, called, and I examined the list in consequence.
Cross-examined. Q. The Incorporated Law Society have nothing to do with this prosecution? A. No.

MR. PRENDERGAST called WORLEY. I live at Rockingham-row, New Kent-road. I have known the prisoner about five or six years—he has borne the character of an honest person—I have consulted him as Mr. Towshend's clerk.

(Three other witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.)
GUILTY .—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Three Weeks.

div0.p: PRESENT—Sir C. MARSHALL, Knt., Ald.; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq. and the Fifth Jury.

div1.p:
2007.
WILLIAM JAMESON
, feloniously forging and uttering an order for payment of 40l. 5s.; with intent to defraud
Sir Peter Laurie, Knt., and others.
BRYAN REYNOLDS . I am cashier of the Argyle-street branch of the Union Bank of London; the chief office is in Princes-street. On 17th Oct. the

prisoner came and presented this check—("Pay Messrs. Dakin 49l. 4s., and debit the same to my account. WILLIAM H. ACRETT.") Mr. Acrett was a customer—I had misgivings about the check, and showed it to the manager—we both spoke to the prisoner. Mr. Clark asked where he got it—he said" From Dakin's, St. Paul's Churchyard"—he was given into custody.

WILLIAM GODFREY (policeman, C 147). I took the prisoner—he said be told the gentleman he had the check from Dakin's, but that was false—I asked where he had it; he said, "From a man in the neighbourhood of Golden-square"—I asked who it was; he said he did not know, no more than he had seen him occasionally before, but did not know his name, or where he lived—I asked him if he wrote it—he said no, but he believed it to be a forgery when he presented it.

WILLIAM HENRY ACRETT . I am a surgeon, of Torrington-square—I keep an account at the Argyle-street branch of the Union Bank of London—this check is not drawn or signed by me or by anybody by my authority—I have seen the prisoner when he was assistant to a chemist in my neighbourhood.

ALEXANDER MAITLAND . I am a chemist, of Torrington-place. The prisoner was my assistant up to 28th March—I know his writing as well as I know his person—the whole of this check is his—I have hundreds of his entries in my prescription-book.
Prisoner. I did not say I believed it to be a forgery, but that I was fearful it was; I had my doubts about it; it is not my writing.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2008.
CHARLES LOWES ,
GEORGE HARRIS , and
WILLIAM THOMPSON
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Harvey, and stealing 1 watch and chain, value 3l. 10s.; 1 sovereign, and 7s.; the property of
Henry Harvey.

MARY ANN HARVEY . I live at Sharp's-buildings, St. James's, Clerken-well; it is my husband's dwelling-house. On 9th Oct., about eight minutes to one, the prisoners came to my house—Harris asked for some dinner—they went up-stairs into the public room on the first-floor—(I knew Lowes and Harris before; I had seen them the day before, in front of the bar; they did not go up-stairs that day)—in about a quarter of an hour I sent my servant up to see that all was safe—she came down and told me something—I went up, and when I got on the first-floor I said to the prisoners," You good for nothing creatures, if you rob a poor woman who has to work as hard for a living as I do, you will rob anybody"—Harris and Thompson were sitting at the table, and Lowes leaning at the back window—Lowes said, "Stuff and nonsense"—I went to the second-floor and found the bed-room door and three drawers open; they all had been locked at eleven o'clock and the key was in my pocket—I missed a sovereign, seven shillings, and a watch and chain of my husband's worth 3l. or 4l.; this is it (produced)—the prisoners were given in charge.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What is your husband's name? A. Henry; he lives there.
Cross-examined by MR. M'MAHON. Q. Are there not two doors to your house 1 A. Yes; persons cannot get to the second-floor without being seen from the bar.
Cross-examined by MR. COCKLE. Q. It was Lowes and Harris you saw on the Monday? A. Yes.
ELLEN DONOVAN . I am Mrs. Harvey's servant—I took up some ale and

tobacco to the prisoners on the first-floor, and left them—about a quarter of an hour afterwards I went up towards the bed-room door, and heard a whistle on the first-floor—I saw Lowes coming out of the bed-room—he said "Lor, I have made a mistake and gone into the wrong room"—I said, "Lor, have you? "and he came down and went into the public room—I informed my mistress—there was no one there but the prisoners.

Cross-examined by MR. M'MAHON. Q. Had you been into the bed-room that morning before? A. No; it was after I passed the public room that I heard the whistle—the stairs face the door; they could see me going up.

THOMAS SOLOMON (policeman, G 54). I took the prisoners—I found a bunch of skeleton keys on Lowes, one of which opens the bed-room door, and another the drawers—they would not givetheir names—they all said they had no address," Put down what you like."

JOHN PORTER (policeman, G 101). I found this watch and chain, a sove
reign, and seven shillings under the seat in the first-floor room at Mrs. Harvey's—the sovereign was wrapped in a little piece of paper.

LOWES—
GUILTY .*— Aged 30.

HARRIS—
GUILTY .*— Aged 33.

THOMPSON—
GUILTY.*— Aged 33.

2009.
CHARLES BAINES
, feloniously killing and slaying
Mary Ann Maine; he was also charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the like offence.
MESSRS. HUDDLESTON and COCKLE conducted the Prosecution,

ELIZA ANDREWS , Jun. I am eleven years old, and live with my mother at 5, Hinton-street, Bethnal-green. I know the prisoner—he lived at our house with a woman that was called his wife—on Wednesday night, 26th Sept., I was called up-stairs a little after ten o'clock—I saw Mrs. Baines standing on the landing—the prisoner was in his room, lying on the bed with his clothes on—Mrs. Baines asked me to get her clothes; I went in, got them off a chair, and took them to her—she said to the prisoner, "I will let you know when I put on my clothes," and he got up and took away her clothes from her, put them on the bed, and lay on them; he then got off the bed again, came on the landing, and kicked her twice—I saw him do it—she was at the top of the stairs—he kicked her in the stomach the first time—she staggered back and held by the bannisters—he had his boots on at the time; they were bluchers—the second time he kicked her it was on the breast—she put her head down on the stairs and cried, and he went and laid on the bed again—she had no clothes on—she was lying down when she received the second kick—she lay down when he first kicked her—she did not lie there a minute, for I asked her if I should help her down, and she came down with me into my mother's room, the front room; she walked down—she then sat on a chair and cried—she asked me to help her down on the floor; I did, and she laid on the floor in our room and groaned—my mother was out—I asked if I should fetch anybody, and I fetched Mrs. Marling, the person next door; and after Mrs. Marling came in my mother came home—the prisoner was given into custody that same night—my mother called him down stairs; she called him three times before he came—Mrs. Baines had been packing up her things during the day; she was going to move, and my mother also—her crockery was packed up in a basket in her room; I saw one piece lying on the floor.
Prisoner. Q. What did Mrs. Baine call me when she got up? what did she have in her hand? A. Nothing.

CATHERINE MARLING . I am the wife of Thomas Marling, of 4, Hinton street. On Wednesday night, 26th Sept., I was sent for to the deceased's house—I went into Mrs. Andrews' room, and saw the deceased there—she was in very great agony, lying on the floor—I assisted her to Mrs. Andrew's bed, from which she was afterwards removed.

ELIZA ANDREWS . I lived at 5, Hinton-street, at the time in question—I came home on 26th, about ten minutes to eleven o'clock, and found the deceased lying on my bed, groaning dreadfully—I called the prisoner down stairs—after some time he came—he kissed his wife, and said some
thing to her in a low tone, which I could not understand—he asked me if I could do anything for her, and I think he asked her to go up-stairs—she said, "I can't"—after that, he said something to her, and she called him a brute—I do not know that he made any answer to that, but he went on and said she was not hurt, she was only shamming, that she did it to collect a mob—he said nothing about the injury, nor did she in his presence—I went with her to the hospital.

DAVID DALE (policeman, K 425). About half-past twelve o'clock on this night I was sent for, and saw the deceased lying on the bed in Mrs. Andrews's room—she appeared to be in a very dangerous state, groaning and in great pain—Mrs. Andrews sent up-stairs for the prisoner—he came down, went up to the deceased, kissed her, and asked if he could assist her to the hos
pital—she said, "Oh, you brute!"—he went and sat down again, and said she was a bthing, she was only shamming to colleet a mob about her—I did not bear anything said as to the cause of the injury—another constable took her in a cab to the hospital—I took the prisoner to the station—he said he had come home very tipsy, that his wife said something to him which he did not like, and a quarrel ensued, and he kicked her.

CHARLES HARPER . I am house-surgeon at the London Hospital, On Thursday morning, 27th Sept., the deceased was brought there—I attended her until her death, which was on the 28th, thirteen hours after her admission—I examined her when she first came—I found no external marks of violence on the abdomen—she was very ill, and suffering a great deal of pain in the abdomen—she seemed better until towards night, when she got worse, and gradually sank—I examined the body after death, I found the membranes of the intestines as if inflammation had taken place in them—I should suppose it to have been of about two days' standing—I also found slight disease of the lungs, but I attached no importance to that as it respects the cause of death; it was of very old standing—I found all the other organs of the body comparatively healthy, at least there was nothing about them to account for death—I attribute the death to peritonitis, or inflammation of the membrane covering the intestines—a kick with a boot would cause that—I should say the inflammation was of about two days' standing, at any rate very short; I could not say the number of hours, I should say between one and two days—I have heard the evidence—I should think an injury inflicted on the 26th might have caused what I saw on the 28th—it would depend very much on the condition of the deceased, and the intensity of the inflammation—I should say she had been in a sickly state before.
COURT? Q, Could the inflammation you saw have existed if it was produced by a kick, without there being some external mark? A. Certainly, from the elasticity of the part.

CATHERINE MOODY . I am the wife of John Moody, a sailor—my daughter lived with the prisoner—she was the wife of Charles Mayne, a ship scraper—her name was Mary Ann—I saw her dead body—it was the same person.

Prisoner's Defence (written.) "I returned from work between eight and nine o'clock, in liquor, and found the deceased in bed; I had been cohabiting with her for twelve months. I went to her and said, 'Well, old girl, how are you?' she said, 'You b----wh----'s son you shall not stop here; get out of bed;' and she laid hold of a basin, with the intention, as I thought, of throwing it at me; I told her she had better be quiet; I turned to go to bed, when she struck me on the right ear; and in the passion of the moment I kicked out at her, not thinking she was within reach; but, unfortunately she was. I beg for mercy."

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2009a.
WALTER GRAHAM
, unlawfully assaulting
Julia Felicia Hough
ton, a child under ten years of age, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2010.
THOMAS CONNELL was indicted
for a rape on
Sarah Ware.
NOT GUILTY .

2011.
THOMAS CONNELL was again indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
Sarah Ware, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Six Months.

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. RECORDER and Mr. Ald. FARNCOMB.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the First Jury.

div1.p:
2012.
RICHARD MATLEY SMITH ,
THOMAS LAWES , and
CHARLES FRASER
unlawfully obtaining 7 soverigns and 1 half-sove
reign; the moneys of
Francis Cuthbertson, by false pretences:—2d COUNT, for a conspiracy.

FRANCIS CUTHBERTSON . I am a bootmaker, and live at 123, Aldersgate-street, City. On Tuesday, 28th Aug., in consequence of a message which I received, I went to the Clarence Hotel, and in the coffee-room there I saw the prisoner, Smith, and a Mr. Collins, in his company—Captain Smith, as he called himself, stated to me that the landlord had gone out of town, or he would have given him the money for this check (producing it)—I unfortu
nately knew Smith for a few weeks before, as a customer—I looked at the check, and finding it was made payable to Mr. F. Collins, who was in Smith's company, and his companion, and knowing Mr. Collins to be a man of pro
perty, and as it was drawn payable to him, I supposed it was a good instru ment, and immediately took out my purse and gave Smith 7l. 10s. for it; that is the amount the check is drawn for—I did not at that time perceive that the check was post-dated, the circumstance of its being crossed was the only thing that induced me to give them the money without its going through a banker—Smith alluded to its being crossed, and said, as the check was crossed, would I give him the money for it, as the landlord was out of town—I did not discover that it was post-dated till next day, when it was going to be sent to the bankers; Smith never alluded to it—I afterwards charged him with giving me a post-dated check—he did not explain the circumstance at all—the only explanation I had was, that

Fraser, the man that drew the check, had the cholera; and then that he had died—the first time I saw him after he gave me the check was on the 3d the day before it was due—he then wished me not to pay it in, as Fraser was ill of the cholera, and could not go to Gravesend—I said I certainly should pay it in, and let it go through the bankers—my brother paid it on the 3d, with other moneys, and it was returned to me on the 5th—I afterwards went to the Commercial Bank; I found they had moved from 3, Moorgate-street, more than twelve months before, and they told me they knew nothing of such parties—I afterwards saw Smith, and spoke to him about the check being returned—he said that Fraser was dead of the cholera—I told him he had given me a forged check—he said it would be paid, I could go to Mr. Lawes, his solicitor, in Moorgate-street, who gave him the check—we had a long conversation—I saw him several times—I afterwards went to Lawes, in Moorgate-street; I told him that I had a forged check, and that Captain Smith had sent me to him; that he told me he had received it from him—I pro
duced it to him—Lawes told me that Fraser had a rich brother at Gravesend, and there had been some misunderstanding, which was the reason the money had not been paid; he did not pay it—I told him Smith said Fraser was dead—he said, "Oh!" and put it off in an au fait, easy sort of way—he said, never mind that, "Come in and see Mr. Hall," that was a gentleman in the front office—I did so; and Mr. Hall stated to me, in Lawes presence, that Fraser's brother was a man of property at Gravesend, and it would ultimately be settled, and he thought I should get the money on the following Saturday; Hall said that Lawes should come to pay the check on the Saturday, and Lawes said it certainly should be paid on Saturday—neither Lawes or any one else came to pay it on the Saturday; it has not yet been paid.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you known Collins before? A. I had; he is a son of Mr. Collins, the grazier, a man of great respecta
bility—seeing Collins name to the check, and his giving it me in Collins' pre
sence, gave me a degree of confidence in it—I cannot say what I should have done if I had not seen his name to it—I cannot say whether his name induced me to pay it—I had no doubt about it being a real transaction, and a good instrument—when I laid the money on the table, Smith took it, and said to Collins," Here Collins, we halve the money when we get it; you take half, and I will take half"—that opened my eyes, but the money was gone then—I have not applied to Collins for the payment of the check—I have applied to Smith, in Collins' presence—I believe Smith's relations are respectable—he has been accustomed to attend the Carence for some years—he has, unfortu
nately, spent all his own, and other people's money; there are other checks the subject of inquiry—his father is dead—I am not quite sure whether he was a Magistrate.
MR. M'MAHON. Q. Do you know whether he paid his bill at the Clarence? A. The landlord told me he owed him 100l.
JAMES BECK . I am clerk at the Gravesend Bank, and have been so nearly six years. We have no customer of the name of Charles Fraser—we had not on 4th Sept., nor ever had.

Cross-examined. Q. Supposing any person were to pay cash, say 50l., and ask you to let it pass through your hands and be made payable to your agents in town, should you allow it to be done? A. Yes; it does not require that the person should be in our books—we would take a single sum of a stranger—the Commercial Bank are correspondents of ours—it is, in fact, the same house, for the purpose of transmitting money; we should

charge a commission on it—if we bad funds for the purpose, we should send money to the Commercial Bank to enable them to pay the person who presented the check—the sum of 7l. 10s. was not paid in on 3d Sept.; there have been no entries of it in our books—I am not the sole person who takes money—it could not be done without my knowing it, because I examined the book—if the clerk who received it entered it properly, I should see it.

MATTHEW KIGHT . I keep the British coffee-house, Blackfriars-road. On Tuesday, 25th Sept., a young man of respectable appearance brought a desk to my house, and asked me if I would oblige him by letting it rem in till the afternoon—I afterwards saw that young man speaking to Lawes at the police-court—I gave the desk to Russell.

GEORGE RUSSELL (City-policeman, 34). On Tuesday afternoon, 25th Sept., I went to Kight's coffee-house—I received this desk (produced)—Kight was present—I found these papers and books in it (produced).

ARTHUR GEORGE HALL . I am a clerk in the Commercial Bank of London. The offices are now in Lothbury—they were removed there in 1840 or 1841, I believe, but I have only been there three or four years—I know Lawes as a former customer—the last transaction he had with us was on 13th April, 1848, as far as my memory serves—this check-book (produced; found in the desk) is one of ours—no doubt he had a check-book when he had an account with us—I have seen the writing on the counterfoils in this check-book—I believe it to be Lawes' to the best of my belief—this memo
randum book (produced; also from the desk) is the one that was issued to Lawes when he was a customer, and this pass-book (also from the desk) was issued to him—the entries in this memorandum-book appear to be in Lawes' writing—this check was presented for payment on 4th Sept., and was refused—we have no customer named Charles Fraser.

Cross-examined. Q. You have change'd the colouring and lithographing of your check-books since my client had the book? A. Yes; these two checks are totally different, but still they belong to the same bank—I do not suppose they came out of this book—we sometimes pay post-dated checks by accident—I can say I did not pay a check of 12l. 10s. for Mr. Lawes' on 4th May, 1849—I inspected the ledger this morning, and Lawes' account seemed to be almost closed—the account was overdrawn—I do not recollect how much—he began with 200l.
JOHN HARVEY (policeman, G 14). I apprehended Lawes in Milk-street, on 22d Sept.—I afterwards took Fraser, searched him, and found these papers on him (marked A and B.)
HENRY FLIGHT . I am a share-broker. I know Fraser, and have seen two or three letters from him—the writing in these memorandum-books, "A" and" B," I believe to be his.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever seen Fraser write? A. No, I merely judge from three or four letters of inquiry I have received, purporting to come from Fraser—I have not acted upon those letters—I talked to Fraser about them. (The following memorandums were read from the books, "Received of Thomas Lawes for drawing two checks, and received to account 1s., leaving 1s. still due by that gentleman, 29th Aug." "Received 3d Sept., of Mr. Thomas Lawes, the balance of 1s. on account of commission.") MR. M'MAHON. Q. Whose writing do you believe the signature to the check to be? A. It don't look to me like Fraser's writing—I cannot swear to it—it does not appear to be at all like it—I do not believe it is his—I do not know the writing of the body—I know none of the writing of the check—I
have no belief about it—Fraser said nothing to me about the check—I do not know the other prisoners at all.

WILLIAM HALL
re-examined. I do not know the writing of the body—I know Lawes' writing—I do not believe the body is Lawes' writing—I do not know Fraser's writing.

FREDERICK COLLINS . I was in the room when the check was handed to Mr. Cuthbertson—I cannot say whether I was in the same box—I do not know the writing of any part of the check—I believe the check is given in my favour—my name is F. Collins.

Cross-examined. Q. You have no doubt that the check was drawn in your favour, have you? A. Well, I cannot say—I believe Smith called me when the check was cashed; I was in another part of the room—while the money was one the table, Smith took some of the money and I some, but how much I cannot exactly say; it could not have been exactly half—I might have had pretty near half of it—I took it because Smith owed me money, and I supposed the check was obtained by honourable means—I did not know it was made payable to me—I had not seen it before—I swear that—I afterwards saw Lawes, and he gave me the money to pay the check, when the case went before the Clerkenwell police-court, that was on a Saturday—he did not give me the money before I appeared, because I went up there first to ask if it was correct—I have the money now—I did not pay it over—I was not allowed to do so—I was given to understand by somebody about the Court, I cannot say exactly who, that it could not be settled, as it had been once, before the Magistrate—the holder of the check never applied to me for it, and so I could not have done it—it was not about this check at all, it was about Mr. Mills' check, that was in the same way—I mean to return the 7l. 10s.—I have not done it, because I have had no application; it will be done—I have no wish to hold another man's money—I was to pay it to Mr. Mills.
Q. Now, on your oath, were you not desired to pay 7l. 10s. to Mr.

Cuthbertson, I only want an answer, yes or no, and just be cautious? A. Well, I cannot state which way it was now, the two transactions have been so mixed up together—I swear 7l. 10s. is all the money I have received for the purpose of paying the parties—that is not all the money I have received of Lawes since 3d Aug.—he did some private business for me—I do not know how much I have received—I have no account—I have not received more than 7l. 10s. from him to pay checks—I have not received 15l. from him since 28th Aug.—I received the 7l. 10s. on the Saturday, and I do not remember that I have received any other sum of him since 28th Aug.—I may have received money on my private account; but not to my recol
lection—I fancy it was previous to that—it was not 50l., I should say it was between 20l. and 30l.—I swear that was not for the purpose of paying the two 7l. 10s. checks—I did not undertake to pay the other 7l. 10s.—the private accounts between us were about some money Lawes had got for me, for which I gave him a bill, which I shall have to take up at the end of this month—I think it is for 30l.—I suppose I received between 20l. to 30l. from him; but I cannot tell—besides that, I have received nothing else except the 7l. 10s.
COURT. Q. Was your name on Mills's check? A. Yes; I saw it at the police-court—I did not see it before Mills had it.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Of course you have paid back the money to the prosecutor, the half of the amount of this check? A. No; I had reason to

believe the account would be made all square with the prosecutor, as far as I was concerned—that was not in order to keep the 7l. 10s. in my own pocket—I have not got it in my pocket now; I can send for it. COURT. Q. They have not indicted you? A. They have not. MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you got 7l. 10s. in the world? A. I have at Pocklington's and Laceys, in Smithfield, my trustees keep my accounts—I can have money by applying to them for it—I cannot draw any
thing out myself.

COURT. Q. What has become of the 7l. 10s.? A. God knows; I can repay it at any time—I suppose it has been spent; since that, money has been obtained by another party, and I did not think this would be brought in question—I have paid away the money, and I have had a party receiving that money through some rather indirect transaction—I would rather not mention names; it would not criminate myself, perhaps I might say more than I should wish; there is nothing very particular about it, but perhaps it might go further into private matters than I should like—it might involve me in another transaction; I do not know whether it would involve me in an indictment.

MR. M'MAHON. Q. Where did you receive the 7l. 10s. from Laws? A. At the Dolphin, in Milk-street; an officer was with me; Lawes was not in custody—it was on the Saturday we went to the police-court, I forget the day of the month—I went from the court to Lawes, to inquire whether there was anything not fair or fraudulent in the transaction—I told him that Smith was then in custody, and I should like him to come up and see whether anything could be done in it.

COURT. Q. Did you give any part of the 20l. or 30l., you received from Lawes to Smith? A. I lent him some money, Smith bad taken up the trans
action on my behalf; at least I let him do the dirty work, going backwards and forwards—he received it for me one day, and brought it me, and had some of it: we were pals together—he was not my agent to raise the money, and we were rather more intimate than I liked—I am not yet twenty years old.

SMITH—
GUILTY
on the 1st Count.. Aged 29.—
Confined One Year.

LAWES and FRASER—
NOT GUILTY

2013.
THOMAS LAWES and
CHARLES FRASER , were again indicted for
unlawfully obtaining 6l. 15s. of
George Mills, by false pretences.—2d COUNT, for a conspiracy.

WILLIAM HUXLEY . I am ostler, at the Clarence Hotel. On Monday, 3d Sept., Smith sent me to Mr. Mills, of Goswell-street, to get a dog-cart for two or three days—he gave me this check (produced) to pay for the hire of it, and to bring him the difference—I went to Mr. Mills and told him I had come to hire a dog-cart for Mr. Smith, of the Clarence Hotel—I gave him the check, and told him to. take the three days' hire out of it—he gave me the difference, 6l. 15s.—I went back and saw Smith in the Clarence-yard, and gave it to him—I saw the dog-cart brought to the yard.

Cross-examined by MR. COCKLE. Q. I believe Mr. Smith went to Rich
mond for three or four days, after that? A. I believe so—he made use of the dog-cart.

GEORGE MILLS . I am a coach-maker, of 171, Goswell-street. On 3d Sept., I received this check from Huxley—not having the cash by me, I drew a check for the difference, 6l. 15s., and gave it to Huxley—I did not at that time notice the date of this check—I paid it into the London and West
minster

Bank next day, the 4th, and on the 5th received it back—it was dated 11th—I have received my own check of 6l. 15s. back from my bankers—I have not received any payment for this check since—I presented it at the Commercial Bank of London on 11th Sept., and the answer was, that there was no account open in such a name, and that in their opinion it was a forgery.
Cross-examined. Q. I suppose Mr. Collins has not paid you any part of it? A. I did not know Mr. Collins—I never saw him till the present transaction.

WILLIAM HUXLEY
re-examined, I got this check for 6l. 15s. from Mr. Mills, got it cashed at a public-house opposite our hotel, and gave the amount to Mr. Smith.

Cross-examined. Q. When Mr. Smith gave you the first check to take to Mr. Mills, did he not say it was post-dated? A. If he did I did not hear him—he was talking something, but I was ordered off in a hurry to Barnet-fair, and did not notice what he said—I could not swear he did not tell me it was post-dated—I do not know what he said.

MATTHEW KIGHT . I keep the British Coffee-house in Blackfriars-road. On Tuesday, 25th Sept., I received this desk from a young man, who I after
wards saw speaking to Lawes at the police-court—I gave it up to Russell that same afternoon, as I received it.
GEORGE RUSSELL (City-policeman, 34). On 25th Sept., I went to Kight and received from him this desk—it then contained the papers and documents that are here now.

ARTHUR GEORGE HALL . I have been, since Jan. 1845, a clerk in the Commercial Bank of London. On 4th Sept., this check was paid to us by the London and Westminster Bank—it was first paid by us to the London and Westminster Bank, but we found out our error and had it back—on searching I found that Charles Fraser, the drawer, had no account at our bank—we do business for the Gravesend Bank—I believe this check has come out of this check-book (produced from the desk)—I cannot point out from what place, but the numbers agree—the counterfoils all bear the same number, 5676—the number of this check is 567—the last figure 6 has been removed—I know Lawes; he once kept an account at our bank—this check-book was issued by us to him—I believe the writing on the counterfoils to be his—the body of this check I also believe to be his—I mean the words that are written "Sept 11, '49. J. F. Collins, Esq., 7l. 10s. on account of the Gravesend Bank," and the figures" 7l. 10s." all the writing part, except Fraser's signature—this was our pass-book with Lawes—I believe the entries in this memorandum-book to be Lawes's writing—the last entry is "1849, Aug. 28. Cash per Smith, 2l. 10s."—I cannot say when Lawes's account with us ceased—the last transaction I am aware of was on 13th April.

Cross-examined Q. Have all these books the same number of checks in them? A. No; they begin at 25 and go up to 500—I have not counted the checks in this book to see whether any are missing—I feel no difficulty in speaking to the body of this check being in Lawes's writing, from the know
ledge I have of it—I should say it is the same character of writing as that on the counterfoils—in my opinion all the body of this check, except the signature, is in one handwriting—there is a slight difference in the colour of the ink with which" Pay to F. Collins" is written. JOSEPH BEADLE. I am a clerk in the Commercial Bank of London.
I produce the book in which is recorded the check-books issued to customers—I find that the number of the check-book issued to Lawes was 5676—the entry is in my own writing.

JAMES BECK . I am a clerk in the Gravesend Bank, and have been so five or six years. During that time no such person as Charles Fraser has kept any account at our bank—there was no money to the credit of such a name OD 4th or 11th Sept. last, nor at any time.
Cross-examined. Q. You do receive money paid in by strangers? A. Yes and pay those sums in London through the Commercial bank.

JOHN HARVEY (policeman, G 14). I apprehended Lawes in Milk-street, on 22d Sept., about half-past two o'clock—I told him the charge, and said be must go to Clerkenwell police-court with me about Smith's business respecting a check—he said he would be dif he would—he said be gave

Smith the check—he then said that Fraser signed the check, and he ought to go as well—I asked where Fraser was—he said on the Exchange, and I went with him to the Exchange—I there found Fraser—I told him I wanted him to go to Clerkenwell police-station—he wanted to know what for—I told him about a check—Lawes then said, "You know you signed your name to that check"—he said, "Yes"—I believe Smith's name was mentioned by a person named Hall—Fraser said if I would wait half an hour he would go, when he had finished his business—I then took him and Lawes in a cab to the station—a person named Hall was also in the cab, he represented himself as being an attorney in Moorgate-street—I did not take him into custody, he went of his own accord—as they were going along Lawes said to Fraser, "Charlie, if the Magistrate should ask you why you gave a check on the Gravesend Bank, tell him you expected the money to be paid in immediately, "and Fraser said" Yes"—I examined Lawes at the station, and found on him this pocket-book, containing these two blank checks (numbered 5676), a 10l.-note, and a quantity of papers—I also searched Fraser, and found on him the papers marked" A "and" B"—I was before the Magistrate when Collins was being examined (looking at the deposition)—this is Mr. Combe's writing (read—"The prisoner Fraser voluntarily states: The signature to the check is in my handwriting; only the signature is in my handwriting; I do not know any
thing about the rest of the handwriting ")—I heard that stated—Lawes after
wards made a statement—he said, "I believe all the handwriting on the check to be in Fraser's handwriting; none of it is mine"—Fraser said, "Most probably I signed the check at Garraway's; I have had transactions of this kind before, but such transactions were always met, and if there is anything wrong, come to me on Monday at twelve o'clock on the Exchange and it shall be all right"—Inspector Brannan is not here; he is ill of the cholera.

Cross-examined. Q. It was a 10l. Bank of England note you found on Lawes? A. Yes; what he said to Fraser in the cab was nearly at the end of our ride—there had been a good deal of conversation—I think what Lawes said was, "You know you signed your name to that check"—I could not say positively that it was not," Did you sign your name to that check?"—I do not know which it was—both charges were not investigated on the first day—I am speaking of the 22nd—Smith had been taken on the night pre
vious—the first charge was Mr. Mills's—the other check was not then produced—they were remanded, and Mr. Cuthbertson's check was brought forward on the second examination.
FREDERICK COLLINS . (This witness was cautioned by the Court that he was not bound to answer any question that might criminate himself.) I cannot

minster Bank next day, the 4th, and on the 5th received it back—it was dated 11th—I have received my own check of 6l. 15s. back from my bankers—I have not received any payment for this check since—I presented it at the Commercial Bank of London on 11th Sept., and the answer was, that there was no account open in such a name, and that in their opinion it was a forgery.
Cross-examined. Q. I suppose Mr. Collins has not paid you any part of it? A. I did not know Mr. Collins—I never saw him till the present transaction.

WILLIAM HUXLEY
re-examined. I got this check for 6l. 15s. from Mr. Mills, got it cashed at a public-house opposite our hotel, and gave the amount to Mr. Smith.

Cross-examined. Q. When Mr. Smith gave you the first check to take to Mr. Mills, did he not say it was post-dated? A. If he did I did not hear him—he was talking something, but I was ordered off in a hurry to Barnet-fair, and did not notice what he said—I could not swear he did not tell me it was post-dated—I do not know what he said.

MATTHEW KIGHT . I keep the British Coffee-house in Black friars-road. On Tuesday, 25th Sept., I received this desk from a young man, who I after
wards saw speaking to Lawes at the police-court—I gave it up to Russell that same afternoon, as I received it.
GEORGE RUSSELL (City-policeman, 34). On 25th Sept., I went to Kight and received from him this desk—it then contained the papers and documents that are here now.

ARTHUR GEORGE HALL . I have been, since Jan. 1845, a clerk in the Commercial Bank of London. On 4th Sept., this check was paid to us by the London and Westminster Bank—it was first paid by us to the London and Westminster Bank, but we found out our error and had it back—on searching I found that Charles Fraser, the drawer, had no account at our bank—we do business for the Gravesend Bank—I believe this check has come out of this check-book (produced from the desk)—I cannot point out from what place, but the numbers agree—the counterfoils all bear the same number, 5676—the number of this check is 567—the last figure 6 has been removed—I know Lawes; he once kept an account at our bank—this check-book was issued by us to him—I believe the writing on the counterfoils to be his—the body of this check I also believe to be his—I mean the words that are written "Sept 11, '49. J. F. Collins, Esq., 7l. 10s. on account of the Gravesend Bank," and the figures "7l. 10s." all the writing part, except Fraser's signature—this was our pass-book with Lawes—I believe the entries in this memorandum-book to be Lawes's writing—the last entry is" 1849, Aug. 28. Cash per Smith, 2l. 10s."—I cannot say when Lawes's account with us ceased—the last transaction I am aware of was on 13th April.

Cross-examined Q. Have all these books the same number of checks in them? A. No; they begin at 25 and go up to 500—I have not counted the checks in this book to see whether any are missing—I feel no difficulty in speaking to the body of this check being in Lawes's writing, from the know
ledge I have of it—I should say it is the same character of writing as that on the counterfoils—in my opinion all the body of this check, except the signature, is in one handwriting—there is a slight difference in the colour of the ink with which "Pay to F. Collins" is written. JOSEPH BEADLE. I am a clerk in the Commercial Bank of London.
I produce the book in which is recorded the check-books issued to customers—I find that the number of the check-book issued to Lawes was 5676—the entry is in my own writing.

JAMES BECK . I am a clerk in the Gravesend Bank, and have been so five or six years. During that time no such person as Charles Fraser has kept any account at our bank—there was no money to the credit of such a name on 4th or 11th Sept. last, nor at any time.
Cross-examined. Q. You do receive money paid in by strangers? A. Yes and pay those sums in London through the Commercial bank.

JOHN HARVEY (policeman, G 14). I apprehended Lawes in Milk-street, on 22d Sept., about half-past two o'clock—I told him the charge, and said he must go to Clerkenwell police-court with roe about Smith's business respecting a check—he said he would be dif he would—he said he gave

Smith the check—he then said that Fraser signed the check, and he ought to go as well—I asked where Fraser was—he said on the Exchange, and I went with him to the Exchange—I there found Fraser—I told him I wanted him to go to Clerkenwell police-station—he wanted to know what for—I told him about a check—Lawes then said, "You know you signed your name to that check"—he said, "Yes"—I believe Smith's name was mentioned by a person named Hall—Fraser said if I would wait half an hour he would go, when he had finished his business—I then took him and Lawes in a cab to the station—a person named Hall was also in the cab, he represented himself as being an attorney in Moorgate-street—I did not take him into custody, he went of his own accord—as they were going along Lawes said to Fraser, "Charlie, if the Magistrate should ask you why you gave a check on the Gravesend Bank, tell him you expected the money to be paid in immediately, "and Fraser said" Yes"—I examined Lawes at the station, and found on him this pocket-book, containing these two blank checks (numbered 5676), a 10l.-note, and a quantity of papers—I also searched Fraser, and found on him the papers marked" A "and" B"—I was before the Magistrate when Collins was being examined (looking at the deposition)—this is Mr. Combe's writing (read—"The prisoner Fraser voluntarily states: The signature to the check is in my handwriting; only the signature is in my handwriting; I do not know any
thing about the rest of the handwriting ")—I heard that stated—Lawes after
wards made a statement—he said, "I believe all the handwriting on the check to be in Fraser's handwriting; none of it is mine"—Fraser said, "Most probably I signed the check at Oarraway's; I have had transactions of this kind before, but such transactions were always met, and if there is anything wrong, come to me on Monday at twelve o'clock on the Exchange and it shall be all right"—Inspector Brannan is not here; he is ill of the cholera.

Cross-examined. Q. It was a 10l. Bank of England note you found on Lawes? A. Yes; what he said to Fraser in the cab was nearly at the end of our ride—there had been a good deal of conversation—I think what Lawes said was, "You know you signed your name to that check"—I could not say positively that it was not," Did you sign your name to that check?"—I do not know which it was—both charges were not investigated on the first day—I am speaking of the 22nd—Smith had been taken on the night pre
vious—the first charge was Mr. Mills's—the other check was not then produced—they were remanded, and Mr. Cuthbertson's check was brought forward on the second examination.
FREDERICK COLLINS . (This witness was cautioned by the Court that he was not bound to answer any question that might criminate himself.) I cannot

remember whether I saw this check before 3d Sept. last—I do not remember seeing it before 3d—I do not think I saw it till it was brought into my bed-room one morning—that was after the 11th, or somewhere thereabout—the landlord of the hotel brought it into my room, and asked me if I knew any
thing about it—he told me that it was given to him by Mr. Mills—that was the first time I saw anything of it—I never saw it in the hands of Lawes, to my recollection—I think, as far as I can call to mind, that was the first time I saw it—I fancy it must have been after 11th Sept.—I think it was after it had been presented at the bank—I have seen it since at the police-court, but I do not remember seeing it before—I cannot positively state whether I saw it produced by Lawes to Smith at the Clarence before 11th Sept.—I might have done so, but not to my recollection.

Q. Did Lawes say, on producing it to Smith or you, in the presence of you both, "I shall give you this check if you can get anybody to cash it?" A. My Lord, am I justified in answering this question, as I am given to understand that perhaps any answer I make may be construed into some participation—I decline to answer the question—I decline answering whether Smith took up the check.

HENRY FLIGHT . I am clerk to Mr. Killick, a sharebroker. These entries in the memorandum-books, marked" A" and "B," I believe to be Fraser's writing (these were read as before)—the signature, "Chas. Fraser," to this check appears similar to the last, but I could not swear to it—I do not believe it to be his, I cannot recognize it as such.
JOHN WHALE . I am a waiter at the Clarence Hotel. Smith staid there for three months, last autumn—Lawes occasionally called to see him, altogether about eight times.

Cross-examined. Q. He had not called for some months or six weeks previous to this transaction, had he? A. That was about the time—I think the last time was about three weeks or a month before they were taken into custody—I did not take particular notice of the time. (Lawes and Fraser received good characters.)

SMITH—GUILTY. Aged 29.—Confined One Year. LAWES—
GUILTY . Aged 49. FRASER—
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Confined Eighteen Months.

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Ald. CARDEN; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq. and the Seventh Jury.

div1.p:
2014.
JOHN WILLIAMS
, unlawfully breaking and entering the Church of St. Mary Somerset in London, with intent to steal.

SARAH BLACK MORE . I keep the keys of St. Mary Somerset Church, Fish-street-hill. I went there on 24th Oct., about two o'clock in the after
noon, and found the lock wrenched off the vestry door, and the door open—I had left it locked on Monday, between twelve and one—I went into the Church from the vestry, and saw the prisoner asleep in one of the pews, covered with cushions—I should not have seen him if I had not removed them—a window was broken.
RICHARD JOHN SIMPSON SERGO . I am Rector of St. Mary Somerset. On 24th Oct. I ordered Mrs. Blackmore to open the vestry for me—the lock
