was wrenched, and the door open—one of the Church candles had been burned, and lucifers were lying about the vestry—a pane of glass was broken in the window, next to the fastening—I saw the prisoner found, and fetched the Churchwarden and a policeman—the poker and some iron had been removed from the vestry.

JAMES STREET (City-policeman, 476). I was sent for, and found the prisoner lying in a pew, covered with cushions—his boots were off—he had a box of lucifers and this knife, which had been recently sharpened, in his pocket—this stone was lying on the pew beside him—I found this poker and piece of iron and gas key hid in the dust-bin—the marks on the vestry door correspond with this iron.
GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

2015.
JOHN DIRKS
, stealing 1 live fowl, price 1l.; the property of
Thomas Easton.
THOMAS EASTON . I live at Woodford—I had my fowl safe on 17th Oct.; I missed it—I went to the Spanish Cock and found it, one hour after I had it safe on my premises—this is it (produced.)

JOHN TURPIN (policeman, K 289). I saw the prisoner pick up something, I went and searched his basket, there was nothing in it but some feathers—I asked him what he had got in his basket, he said, "Nothing now"—I said, "I shall find the fowl in the bushes, dead"—he said, "No, you will not find it dead"—this is the cock, it is alive.

WILLIAM VOWLES (policeman, K 275), I found this fowl near the spot where Turpin met the prisoner—the feathers in the basket correspond with the feathers of the fowl.
NOT GUILTY .

2016.
WILLIAM CRANBY
, stealing 51lbs. weight of lead, value 5s.; the goods of
Nicholas Charrington and others.

JOHN WILLIAM MANNING (policeman, K 5). In consequence of informa
tion, I went to the house of Moses Johnson, at Stratford, at half-past seven o'clock in the evening, on the 12th Oct.—he produced this lead, and from what he said, I went to "The Pigeons," and saw the prisoner—I asked him if he knew anything of any lead—he said, "No"—I repeated the question, and he said, "What lead do you mean, the lead in the stable?"—I said, "Have you sold any lead?"—he said, "No "two or three times—I took him to How station, and he looked down at this lead in the charge-room, and said, "It is no use saying I did not take the lead, I did; I took it off the roof of the stable at the back of Mrs. Laythorpe's"—I compared this lead with some in the stable, and it corresponded exactly with the lead of the scullery, and with the lead of the gutter called "the drip."

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Did you not follow Johnson from the stable to his own house? A. I did not, I had never been in the stable before—I know the roof of the stable—I cannot say how long it is ago since new lead was put there—I should say it is about three months—I knew Mr. Laythorpe before he died—he has been dead above three months—I think the lead was not put on before he died—I think Mrs. Laythorpe is not here, I saw her here yesterday—I think the prisoner has been ostler there about two
years—I have been on that beat four years—the prisoner has not lived there all that time, he lived in Leytonstone before that—I did not ask him if he had stolen any lead.

SAMUEL SAXBY . I am a zinc-worker, and reside at Stratford—I accom
panied the officer to "The Pigeons," and compared this lead produced with other lead in the stable and scullery—they corresponded—I found marks in the lead corresponding with the drip on the roof—this piece came off the gutter—here are marks where it had been dressed over the drip.

Cross-examined. Q. In whose employ are you? A. Mr. Little's—I repaired the gutter with zinc, in August—I was told to remove the lead, and to put zinc—there had been a portion of the lead taken away before—I threw the lead off the roof, and gave it to the ostler—that was the last I saw of it—I never sent to take it away—I threw it down outside the stable, and left it—I was told there was other lead there.
ALFRED HEAD . I am a partner of Nicholas Charrington and others—we are lessees of" The Pigeons."

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know anything about when this other old lead was taken off the stable? A. The gutter had been stripped some months before, under my direction—if the prisoner had not taken the lead, our sur
veyor would have sent to remove it—I cannot tell when he ought to have sent for it—I think he did send for it some time afterwards, and could not find it—our surveyor charges so much for what he does to the houses—the old lead is not his perquisite, it would come back to the brewery.

MOSES JOHNSON . I am a marine-store dealer. On 12th Oct. I purchased about 50lbs. of lead of the prisoner, I gave him 3s. 6d. for it, and stood a quar
tern of gin—I saw him going down Stratford—he said he had two or three pieces of lead, if I liked to buy them—I went and bought them, and brought them away.
Cross-examined. Q. What time was this? A. Between five and six o'clock in the evening—I have lived there about three years and a half-there were persons about the yard.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Two Months.

2017.
GEORGE ARCHER
, stealing, on 18th Sept., at Chingford, 1 pepper-box, 2 spoons, ¾lbs. weight of tobacco, 1 handkerchief, and 1 basket, value 25s.; the goods of
Jane Williams, in her dwelling-house; and after
wards burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house: to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Two Years.

2018.
THOMAS EADE
, stealing 500 carrots, value 9s.; the goods of
William Adams, his master.

JAMES CHAMBERS . I am foreman to William Adams, of West Ham, Essex. On 14th Oct., 1848, the prisoner was in his service, and was sent to town with sixty dozen of carrots, in a wagon, to Mr. Gregory, of Spitalfields-market—I made out a note of the quantity, and the carter's name; he was the prisoner—I left it with Cordery, the watchman, to give to the prisoner—the prisoner had no authority to deliver any of the carrots on the road, but to take them to the salesman—I did not see him start or come back—I did not see him again till he was in custody, nearly twelve months after—he was in regular employ—he never came back to his master—the carrots were Mr. Adams's property until delivered to Mr. Gregory, for sale.

RICHARD IMRAY . I live at Saville-road, Mile-end-road. On 14th Oct., 1848, about half-past three in the morning, I was walking to town, and as I passed the Fountain public-house, in the Mile-end-road, I saw a wagon with carrots in it, and saw the prisoner and two other persons unloading the carrots into the Fountain stable—the prisoner was on the wagon, and the two others carrying them into the stable—I afterwards saw the prisoner go on with the wagon—about three-quarters of an hour afterwards I went with a police-man to the stable, and saw the carrots there—he took charge of them, and I gave information to Mr. Gregory.
Prisoner. Q. How could you tell me from the other men by that light? A. The shutter was down at the Fountain, and the gas shone on you.

EDWARD ABRAMS . I am foreman to Mr. Gregory, a salesman of Spitalfields-market. On the morning of the 15th the prisoner brought a wagon of carrots there—there were six or seven wagons came that morning from Mr. Gregory, and one man brought a note of the whole—the prisoner left his wagon, took an empty one, and went to load some dung—Mr. Imray then gave me infor
mation—I examined the wagon, and found the carrots had been disturbed, and there was a space where some had been taken from—I then went to the stable at the Fountain, and found three dozen and two, bunches of carrots, which I compared with the others and found them to be the same—Mr. Gregory sells entirely for Mr. Adams—I can swear they were Mr. Adams's carrots—we told over the remainder of the carrots, and there were three dozen and three punches short—I went after the prisoner to Theobald's-road, where he was to load the dung, and found the wagon and four horses there, and no driver—I did not see him again till this Oct.

CHARLES ROWBURY (policeman, K 347). I received information, and looked after the prisoner, but did not find him till 19th last Sept, when I saw him on top of a wagon in Stratford—I took him into custody—he said if he had done anything wrong he must suffer for it.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

2019.
ELIZABETH KERR
, stealing 30 yards of flannel, value 25s.; the goods of
Charles Thomas Hackman; having been before convicted: to which she pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

2020.
MARTHA CLOTHIER
, stealing 4 knives, value 2s., and 2 napkins, value 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Bull, her master: to which she pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 47.—
Confined Three Months.

2021.
JAMES THOMAS
, stealing 1 sovereign; the moneys of
William Hawley, in the dwelling-house of
John Hawkins: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 12.——
Confined Six Months.

2022.
SARAH CLARK
, stealing 23lbs. weight of rags, value 3s. 2d.; the goods of
Ann Lawrence, her mistress; also
2 candlesticks, and 1 glass-box, value 4s.; the goods of
Thomas Pettafor: to which she pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 20. —Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

2023.
HENRY THORNTON
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Mark Frederick Boorer, and stealing 3 shirts, and other articles, value 22s. 6d.; the goods of
Henry Bishop; and 1 candlestick and tobacco-box, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of the said George Mark Frederick Boorer: to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

2024.
JAMES SMITH
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Edward Cobley, at Greenwich, on 12th Oct., with intent to steal: to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment for burglary against the prisoner.)

2025.
JOHN MEE
, feloniously stabbing and wounding
Harriet Emma Fauchon, on her left cheek, with intent to disfigure her.

(MR. HORRY, for the prisoner, proposed that he should plead GUILTY to an assault. MR. SLEIGH, for the prosecution, thought as the JURY were charged, that course could not be taken, but on the prisoner stating that he was guilty of the assault, the JURY found that verdict.)

GUILTY
of an Assault. Aged 48.—
Confined Six Months.

2026.
MARY LEAHAM
, stealing 2 towels, 1 handkerchief, 2 purse
rings, 1 sovereign, 5 sixpences, 29 groats; and 2 threepenny-pieces, the pro
perty of
George Mason, her master: to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

2027.
MARY MULCHNOCK
, stealing 2 shillings; the moneys of
George Vere Goldfinch, her master.

GEORGE VERE GOLDFINCH . I am a linen-draper, at Deptford; the pri
soner was in my service. For some reason, on 27th Sept. I marked four sixpences, nine shillings, and two half-crowns, and put them in the till—I went to tea, and the prisoner came to mind the shop, which was part of her duty—I left no one in the shop but her—I went back into the shop in half an hour, and she immediately left—I then went to the till and missed two shillings—I went down-stairs, called the prisoner from the wash-house, and said, "You have taken two shillings out of the till"—she said she had not, and I might search her—I called a policeman, and had her taken in charge—he afterwards produced these two marked shillings to me (produced)—they are two of those I put in the till.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Who lives in the house besides you? A. My mother and a little boy, my sister's child, about nine years old—he is not here—I went into the kitchen to tea—my mother occasionally serves in the shop—there was only marked money in the till—my mother, brother, his wife, and the little boy and I had tea together—when I went back from tea, I left the others down-stairs.

EDWARD BENJAMIN SCOTT (policeman, R 71). I took the prisoner into custody, and took her to the station—I then went back to the prosecutor's, and found the two shillings I have produced in a beading just over the sink.
NOT GUILTY .

2028.
CHARLES HINCHEY
, stealing 1 pair of trowsers, value 6s.; the goods of
Richard Parry and another: having been before convicted.

CHARLES DAVIS . I am salesman to Richard Parry, of Deptford, clothier. On 1st Oct., between five and six o'clock I missed a pair of trowsers from the door-post, which I had seen safe half an hour previous—these are them (pro
duced)—they are Richard Parry and Son's property.

JOHN WHITE (policeman, R 180). On 1st Oct. I was on duty in Dept
ford—I saw the prisoner, with two other boys, loitering about Mr. Parry's shop about three-quarters of an hour—they then went to the shop, and after remaining a short time, left—I turned round, and saw the prisoner putting something under his coat; he was then about five yards from the shop—I pursued him, and just before I overtook him, he dropped this pair of trowsers—he said, "I did not take them"—I took him to the station.
Prisoner's Defence. My father won't keep me; it was not me that stole them.
DAVID OVENDEN (policeman, R 343). I produce a certificate—(read Charles Hinchey, convicted June, 1849, and confined one month, and once whipped)—I was present—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2029.
JAMES MANSFIELD
, feloniously assaulting
William Towner, with intent to rob him.

WILLIAM TOWNER . I am a boiler-maker, of Derwent-street, East Greenwich. On Saturday night, 22d Sept., about a quarter-past twelve o'clock, I was alone on the Creek-road, which leads to the Creek-bridge, at Deptford—I had 6l. within a few halfpence in my waistcoat-pocket—when I was near the bridge, the prisoner came up to me, took hold of my arm, and insisted on my going with him—I looked in his face, and said, "I want nothing of you; you have not been in my company, and I want to have nothing to do with you"—I then turned to avoid him, and got away—he then came up to me suddenly, and said, "You have got money, and I will have it"—I said, "You shall not have it"—I told him the money was my mate's and my own, and I had to take 2l. to my mate's wife—I got away from him, and he came after me unawares, and caught me somewhere in the ankle and the back of my head, and knocked me down, knelt on me, and kicked me in the nose and mouth, and when I found he would take my life if I did not give him the money, I hallooed "Murder!" and put my hand in my pocket, folded the money up in my hand, and rolled on the side where the money was—the prisoner felt all round the other side of me—Mr. Bond and the policeman then came to my assistance—I received injuries about the loins, the back of my head was cut very much where it fell on the stones; and my eyes, nose, and mouth, were also very much cut by his kicking me—I had never seen him before—he appeared sober.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not see me in your company that night, at Sullivan's public-house? A. No; I did not order some beer there without being able to pay for it—Vickers and Rayman and a cabman had been in my company that night—we were at the Red Cow, the Red Horse, and the Wheatsheaf—we had a quartern of rum and a pint of beer between three of us—we had nothing at the Wheatsheaf—I had left there about five minutes past twelve o'clock—you must have heard them tell me to take the money home, and to take it the first thing in the morning—you were going the same way that I was—you did not wish me good-night—I told you to go away, and I would give you the price of a pot of beer—I did not say," Shove on, you red
coated fool"—the policeman did not come till about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour after you first came—it was a dozen steps off that you came up the second time—you struck me with your foot twice—I swear I had nearly 6l. in my pocket; 5l. in gold, and the remainder in silver—I could not have pre
vented your getting the money if you had known where it was—I had had

one glass of rum at the Red Cow—I had got the money for my work at Kew
bridge, and I was going home to my wife.
MR. PAYNE. Q. Where did you part with your two mates? A. At the bottom of Union-street—the prisoner may have been at the Red Cow, and heard what was said about the money, but I did not see him.

CHARLES BOND . I am a poulterer, and live at 3, Church-street, Dept
ford. On this night I was at my father's house in the Creek-road, and about twenty minutes past twelve o'clock I heard a cry of "Murder!" I ran out, and saw the prisoner kneeling on Towner and striking him—he made a kick at him, but instead of kicking him he kicked me—I immediately pulled the prisoner off—he ran up the road, calling" Police!"—I ran after him, caught him, and with assistance kept him till the police came—he knocked me down and tore my coat—he said if he had his pricker, or dagger, or sticker, he would pot an end to his b—y life—I think he said sticker—Towner had been drinking a little, but knew what he was about.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see me kneel on him? A. Yes; and your hands were on his waistcoat-pocket when I pulled you off—I was never convicted, and was never a witness on any occasion—I am in work at the present time—I get 5s. 6d. a day, and lose money by coming here.

WILLIAM WELTON (police-sergeant, R 40). I heard a cry of" Murder! "and" Police! "went in the direction, and found the prisoner in the act of running away—he had his arms up, as if he was going to make a start—I saw Towner bleeding, and all over mud and dirt—he pointed out the prisoner, and said he had assaulted and attempted to rob him—I said he must go with me—he was very obstreperous going along, and I was obliged to get a man and the prosecutor to assist me—the prisoner kicked the prosecutor as we went along, and said he should like to kill the b—r, and said, "If I live to get out of the station I shall mark you; I shall serve you out"—I con
sider Towner was perfectly sober, but he was so injured that he had the appearance of being not so.

Prisoner. Q. What did I say? A. That you should like to kill him—I suppose you meant Towner and not yourself—you had had some drink, but knew what you were about—the prosecutor was so weak from the injuries that he was led home, passed on from one policeman to another on their beats. Prisoner's Defence. I was going through the streets to my quarters, and met the prosecutor, and asked where I could get some drink; he said, "Go to hell, you b—y soldier!"" Shove on, you red-coated fool! "and used words of a most exciting nature, my temper could not resist it, and I turned back and struck him till he fell; when he was down, he cried" Murder! "and" Robbery!" and that excited my temper; he accuses me because I gave him the blow he deserved.

The prisoner called JAMES PETER QUIN. I am sergeant of the prisoner's regiment, and have known him about eighteen months—his character for honesty is bad.
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

2030.
MARGARET KING
, stealing 1 coat, and other articles, value 17s. 6d.; the goods of,
Henry Houghton Reyeley, her master: to which she pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

2031.
THOMAS SMITH
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Peter Cornish, and stealing 1 pocket-book, value 4d., his property.

PETER CORNISH . I live at 5, John-street, in the parish of St. Olave, Southwark, and am a tailor. On 14th Oct. I left home about nine o'clock in the morning—I left my room door locked; I returned a little after eleven; my room door was still locked—I unlocked it and went in, and saw the prisoner lying in the bed with his clothes on—I asked him what he did there—he said he came there to sleep—I asked how he got in, but that question he would not answer—I found a little drawer was open, and two shillings and a pocket-book had been taken away—the pocket-book was found in the bed, and one shilling laid on the table.

JAMES BURTON (policeman, M 277). I was called in—I found the prisoner standing by the side of the bed—I saw a female take up the pocket-book between the beds where the prisoner had been lying—the prisoner said he came there to sleep; and he said at the station that he did not steal anything—he was quite sober.

Prisoner's Defence. On that Sunday morning I went to see a party there who lived in the bottom floor; I went in that room and laid down for half an hour.
GUILTY —Aged 21.—
Confined One Year.

2032.
JOHN ARNOLD and
JAMES ARNOLD
, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 2l. 10s., and 31bs. weight of leather, 3s.; the goods of
William Chapman, the master of John Arnold: to which

JOHN ARNOLD peaded—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Nine Months.
JAMES ARNOLD pleaded—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

2033.
GEORGE COPPIN
, stealing 2 sixpences, 1 penny, and 1 half
penny; the moneys of
Richard Bird, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined One Month.

2034.
JOSEPH MINCHEM
, stealing 5¼lbs. weight of lamb, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
William Head, his master.

GEORGE WARD . I keep the Horse and Groom, in Walworth-road—the prosecutor lives opposite me. On 21st Sept., about twelve o'clock, I saw the prisoner take down a leg of lamb, or mutton, and give it to a woman who swept the crossing—she wrapped it in her apron, and appeared to hesitate which way to go—the prisoner held up his knife, and she went in the direc
tion he pointed out—she returned in about twenty minutes—she did not pay for the lamb.

Cross-examined by MR. COCKLE. Q. Do you know the woman's name? A. I know her by sweeping the crossing—I believe she is well known—I was on the other side of the way when I saw the prisoner take the meat.

WILLIAM HEAD . I am a butcher, and live at the corner of West-street, Walworth-road, opposite Mr. Ward's—the prisoner was in my service nine or ten months. On Friday, 21st Sept., I went to Smithfield, and on my return Mr. Ward told me of this—the prisoner was not then at home—I went to the station, and they sent a policeman with me—the prisoner came home, and I gave him and the woman in charge—I told the prisoner I wanted him to come with me—Mr. Ward had told me he had stolen a leg of lamb—he said he

knew nothing about it; he had not left the front—when he was at the station he told me he had taken the leg of lamb for his Sunday's dinner, and it was at home at his wife's—he told me his residence was in Lock's-fields—I went there and told his wife I had come for a leg of lamb that a woman had left a short time back—she said, "I hope nothing has happened"—I said, "I want the leg of lamb"—the prisoner's son took me to the place.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner has a wife? A. Yes, and eight children—his wages were 15s. a week, his board, and a joint of meat for his Sunday's dinner—at the time he said that he had not left the front, he was in custody—I never heard that he had been in business for himself—before he entered into my permanent employ he jobbed for me on Fridays and Saturdays, as an extra man—on Sundays he used to take what meat he pleased, in my sight—it is usual amongst butchers to give a bit of meat for dinner on Sundays.
COURT. Q. Was the prisoner one of your salesmen? A. Yes; he was put outside the shop to sell meat, which was put inside to be weighed.
JOHN THOROGOOD (policeman, P 180). I took the prisoner on 21st Sept.

I told him at the station what he was charged with—he said he knew nothing about it; he had not moved from the front—I asked him where he lived—he said in Lock's-fields—I said it was a wide place; it was no use to seek for it unless he gave some other direction.
NOT GUILTY .

2035.
JAMES TUGWELL
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Ann Digweed, and stealing 1 half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, and 3 shillings; her property.

ANN DIGWEED . I am a widow, and live in High-street, Lambeth. On the morning of 4th Oct. I was awoke by a noise while I was in my bedroom, the back room on the first-floor—I got up, lita candle, and went up-stairs to my brother—I said I fancied there were thieves in the house—I went down, and found the doors open, which had been shut the night before about half-past twelve o'clock—I saw a ladder against the back-yard door—I did not then perceive that anything was lost—I afterwards missed the money stated—I went through the shop to get a policeman, and in the shop I found a coat and pair of shoes—the policeman found the prisoner on the roof of the next house—he had one coat on but no shoes—he owned that the shoes in the shop were his.
ROBERT DAVIS (policeman, L 102). I found the prisoner on the roof of the next house—I found a pane of glass had been taken out, and a person had got through the sky-light.

GUILTY .— Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2036.
HORACE KNIGHT and
JANE CLARK
, feloniously forging and uttering an order for 1l. 14s.; with intent to defraud
William Amos : also,
forging and uttering an order for 5l.; with intent to defraud
William Robinson: to which

KNIGHT pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined One Year. Mr. O'BRIEN offered no evidence against CLARK—
NOT GUILTY .

2037.
EDWARD DRISCOLL
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Lovell, with intent to steal.

SARAH LOVELL . I live at 4, Maryland-buildings, Rotherhithe; my father, James Driscoll, keeps the house. About a quarter before one o'clock, on the 24th Sept., I was awoke by a noise—I threw up the sash and saw the prisoner getting out of the parlour window—he turned and held up his fist, and said, "I am sorry I did not do for the lot of you"—I went down stairs, and found the parlour window open; it had been safe between eight and nine o'clock the night before—the window was shut down, but not fastened—the prisoner lodged next door to us at that time, but the people have removed since he has been in prison.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. YOU say the window was shut the night before? A. Yes, my sister fastened it—my sister has had a few words with the landlady of the house where the prisoner lived—the prisoner was brought back by the policeman immediately.

ELIZA LILLIE . I am the sister of the last witness—I am the wife of James Robert Lillie—he is mate of a ship—I live in the house with my sister—I shut the parlour window shutters between eight and nine o'clock that night—I afterwards heard a noise, and went and awoke my sister.

DAVID FIGG (policeman, M 33). I was on duty, and heard a cry of" Police!"—I saw the prisoner run out from the court—I asked him what was the matter; he said he did not know—he ran, and I ran and caught him—I said he must come back with me—he said he would not, and resisted violently—with the assistance of a private watchman I took him back—Sarah Lovell saw him and identified him directly—he was sober—he said he would knock my by brains out.

Witness for the Defence. MARIA DRISCOLL. The prisoner lodged with me—I am no relation of his—he has borne a good character—he has been in the habit of coming home late and getting in at the window in my absence—there has been a little quarrel between Mrs. Lillie and me.
NOT GUILTY .

2038.
REUBEN WARREN
, stealing 1 sovereign, and 1 5l. Bank-note; the moneys of
Thomas Sargent, his master: to which he pleaded
GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

2039.
HENRY LEEKS was indicted
for embezzlement.

JOHN WEATHERHEAD . I am principal superintendent of the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway. The prisoner was head clerk in the booking-office at the London-bridge station—Mr. Francis is the second clerk. I know the funnel through which the tickets pass; it is supplied with tickets from a drawer, where the tickets are placed in rows consecutively—when tickets are required for the runnel they are taken out of the drawer and put into the funnel—they should be taken consecutively as they run—at the close of the proceedings, the number given, will indicate the number of tickets issued from the funnel. In consequence of information I received on 3d Sept. I communicated with Mr. Slight on Tuesday, 4th Sept., but I had examined the drawers from which the tickets are supplied to the funnel, on Monday night—in the course of business the person issuing the tickets has no right to take any tickets from the drawer unless the funnel is exhausted, and then he is to take them consecutively, not promiscuously—on the Monday evening I found the number of tickets that should be in the drawer, was correct, but some of them evidently had been taken out of the drawer and

used, and returned—in the ordinary course of business none of the tickets in the drawer should bear the stamp of a date—I selected thirty-one of them—these are them—on the greater part of them there is the stamp of the date—it is more visible on some than on others—on the Saturday night previous, I have no doubt that the prisoner had the issuing of the tickets for the Brighton railway by the seven o'clock train—on finding these thirty-one tickets on the Monday, I sent for the prisoner on the Tuesday morning, and for the auditor of the Company—I took the drawer and took out the tickets—I pointed out the tickets I have here now, and laid them on the table—I said to the prisoner, "These tickets have evidently been issued incorrectly out of the drawer, and you must account to me how they were issued"—he hesitated for some time, and then said it was easy to account for it, or words to that effect:" I issued them myself"—I then said he could not carry out the system of thus robbing the Company, unless he had persons to assist him at Brighton, and I named a person, Mr. Springett, a guard, and he said that Springett assisted him in carrying it out—I then said there should be a ticket-collector who was partly concerned in it—I did not mention any name, but he mentioned the name of a ticket-collector, the name of Cheeseman—I then asked him if it was the first time he had done it, or if it was the first time he had been guilty of it, and how the money was disposed of—he said then," jointly, "or that the parties at Brighton would not have joined in it without having part of the money—I then took the prisoner to Brighton, to have it investigated by a Magistrate—I found these thirty-one tickets did not run consecutively—I cannot say what was the lowest number in the drawer which had not been issued, but the lowest number on the books on Saturday was one between 400 and 500, and the funnel only contained about 250, so that the lowest number would be between 700 and 800.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. This conversation, in which the prisoner seems to have made a most ample confession, was in the presence of Mr. Slight? A. Yes; what I have deposed to as having taken place, was in my office—Mr. Slight was present all the time—he was not making notes—there was another gentleman there, Mr. Hemingway, my clerk, who writes in my office—there were no notes taken—I speak from memory—these words were spoken between us—I believe I spoke the first words—I am able to speak positively—I took the tickets out of the drawer, laid them on the table, and said, "These tickets have been issued incorrectly; you must account to me how they have been issued; "these are the thirty-one tickets?—I said, "These have been improperly issued"—he hesitated some time, and did not give an answer; he then said they were easy to account for, he issued them himself—I then went on to ask questions with Mr. Slight, just as we thought well to investigate the matter—we went on to say, "It could not have been carried on unless there were persons to assist you at Brighton"—I will not be certain whether I said that, or Mr. Slight—I will not be certain whether it was said, "This could not be carried on, "or," This could not be done"—he still hesitated, and at length I told him I would tell him one of the parties who carried it out, or assisted him in it—I did not say, "through the fault of some person at Brighton"—I did not suspect a fault—I named Springett, who has been taken since, and the Magistrate discharged him—the prisoner named another man, Cheeseman—he is not in custody—he has been discharged—I think it was myself used the term" robbery"—if I did not say "robbery," I said words to that amount—I cannot recollect what words I used—the tickets are placed consecutively in the funnel and in the drawer—it was the

prisoner's duty to put them into the funnel; whether he had done so I cannot answer—when the funnel becomes vacant it is filled from the drawer—it was the prisoner's duty to fill it, and then the tickets are issued by the clerk from the funnel—it was the prisoner's duty to issue tickets from the desk when the other clerks were off duty—it was his duty to supply the funnel from the drawer—some other clerks may have done it in his absence—the drawer from which these tickets are taken, is accessible to all the clerks on duty in the office, the prisoner having the charge of it—he was head clerk—he had the key of the drawer, and was supposed to lock it when he went away—the other clerks could get the tickets in his absence, by sending to him for the key—it seldom occurred that the funnel would be destitute during one or two trains—it was the duty of the head clerk to supply it—he was the sole person who was answerable for it—he issued the tickets to the passengers for the seven o'clock train that night—he was not out of his regular line of duty—he occasionally served a train—he had the charge then both of the funnel and the train—he was well competent to do the duty—he had not more than his regular duty to perform at that time—it may be that during that train he had not to supply the funnels, or may be none were deficient—the Saturday seven o'clock train is generally a very busy train—there were other clerks there—I cannot say whether they were supplying the trains; I did not take notice—the prisoner served the first and second-class—there may be another clerk who served part of them—I have the book here, to show how many tickets are acknowledged to be issued that night; "on 1st Sept., for the second-class, thirty-eight"—I have not the first-class book here—this book would show all the second-class tickets that were issued that night, if it were correctly kept, and none but the proper number from the funnel had been issued—the prisoner kept this book that night—here is the commencing number, 45, and the closing number is 83, which makes thirty-eight—he charges himself with thirty-eight tickets that night—I have a book which tells the amount of money I received from him that night, but it is not here—the money embezzled for these tickets would not be accounted for—the money was correct to a farthing according to the tickets he accounted for—he accounted to me about a quarter before nine o'clock that night—I cannot tell how much money he paid me.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. IS it his duty to account at night for the money received in the day? A. Yes; I did not check it with the number of tickets that night, but afterwards—the money he accounted for was correct with the number of tickets that appeared to have been issued—the money is accounted for to me every night—I cannot then refer to the tickets—the money for the thirty-eight second-class tickets in this book, was accounted for to me by the prisoner that night—I should not have found out afterwards that there had been more tickets issued than he accounted for—the tickets were in the Audit-office—if tickets had been taken out of their order, issued, and money received for them, and the tickets put into the drawer again, I could not have detected them that night; but afterwards, when the account went through the Audit-office, I could.

Q. If the tickets had been taken out of their regular numbers from the drawer, issued to passengers, the money received for them, and the tickets had been sent back from Brighton, and put back into the drawer, could you have discovered that the money had been taken for them? A. No—the prisoner was the chief clerk; he had the sole superintendence of the tickets in the drawer, and he signed all papers—there was a lock to the drawer—the prisoner had the care of the key—if any other clerks wanted tickets to supply

the funnel, they would apply to him—it was his duty before he left, to see that the funnel was supplied—it was not the duty of any other person to supply tickets from the drawer to the funnel, but they might have done it if the prisoner were not there—I did not take any note of the conversation that took place between me and the prisoner—Springett and Cheeseman were dis
charged before the Magistrate, and they sent in their resignation to the Com
pany two days afterwards.

FREDERICK GEORGE FRANCIS . I am a clerk in the London and South Western Railway Company, in the same office as the prisoner; I was under him. In consequence of suspicion, I examined the drawer under the funnel, on Sunday, the 2d of Sept., between seven and eight o'clock in the morning—I missed about thirty tickets—I made a communication to Mr. Weatherhead the same day, and I went to the drawer with him on the Monday evening—I found the tickets were there then, and they were not there the day before—I examined those tickets, and they appeared to have a stamp on them—the tickets in the drawers should not have any stamp—in a great pressure of business I should have recourse to the drawer, whether the prisoner were absent or present—the numbers run consecutively, and would be issued con
secutively—the report of the tickets was made in the office by the clerk who booked the train.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Do you know that Mr. Blunden issued the tickets for the seven o'clock train? A. No; I believe he booked the trains for the Saturday—I know the drawer in which the tickets are kept—I am not aware that the key was kept by any one—the drawer was always open when I have been there—I know the office well—I know the funnel—it has been fed by every body there; that is to say, by every clerk-quite as much by one man as another—it was very rarely that the prisoner himself issued any tickets—he did occasionally, to relieve another clerk, if someclerk called on him to relieve him, or if another clerk were absent-sometimes, in consequence of a pressure of business at a fair or races, another clerk would be sent for—I recollect one of the Dovor railway men getting there and serving our passengers.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Who was there on the 1st of Sept.? A. Myself and Mr. Blunden, and the prisoner; I saw no other person—if I or any other clerk go to the drawer, we take the tickets in regular turn—there was no other person besides me and Mr. Blunden, and the prisoner, issuing tickets—I never took any tickets out of their regular number—it was the duty of the clerks who issued the tickets, to supply the funnel from the drawer.

EDWARD MARTIN BLUNDEN . I am one of the clerks in that office. There were no other persons there but myself, Mr. Francis, and the prisoner—the persons from the Dovor train have free access to the office—they go down to a place underneath to wash their hands—they had nothing to do with issuing the tickets on the 1st of Sept.—nobody but me and the prisoner, and Mr. Francis, issued tickets on the 1st of Sept.—I supplied tickets from the drawer to the funnel during that day—I took them in their regular turn.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I suppose the funnel is not kept locked? A. There is a mode of locking it by a slide draw in front; it never was locked—I have one key of the funnel now, but I do not think there was one then—I had one key of the drawer, but it never was locked; that was the only key of the drawer.
MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Do you keep the key of the drawer now? A. Yes; I kept it when the prisoner was there—it was the only key in the office—I

never took any tickets out except those in regular numbers—the prisoner had the care of the cash received—the price of a second-class ticket was 8s.—the clerk who issued the tickets took the money, and paid it to the prisoner.

FREDERICK SLIGHT . I am accountant to the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway Company—the prisoner has been in the employ of the Com
pany; in consequence of information from Mr. Weatherhead, I examined the tickets in the drawer on the Tuesday morning—I found a number of them which appeared to have been stamped—those tickets ought not to have been in the drawer with the stamps on them—we sent for the prisoner, and called him to account for these tickets being in the drawer in this manner—I asked him for an explanation—he said, "It is no use, I must confess"—we further asked who had assisted him in the fraud—he said, "It was Springett the guard"—we then said there must have been a ticket-collector connected with the matter, and asked who it was—he said, "It was Cheeseman, the ticket-collector at Brighton"—we then asked him whether Springett and he had shared the money—he said, "Of course, Springett would not do anything of that sort for nothing"—the amount of thirty-one tickets at 8s. each, would be 22l. 8s.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you quite correct about this conversation? A. That is the conversation, I believe pretty nearly the words that were used—I believe it was the prisoner who mentioned Springett's name—I will not be quite clear whether Mr. Weatherhead said, "Was it Springett? "and the prisoner said" Yes, "or the prisoner said it—I am sure the prisoner used the word" confess; ""I must confess it"—we had called on him to explain; and he said it was no use, he must confess it—the conversation was very hurried—I had merely time to recollect the real points of the conversation—I will not undertake to say that the word "fraud" was used; I have told the substance of the conversation—the prisoner had been at the London station about nine months—he was before that at Brighton. (The prisoner received an excellent character.)
NOT GUILTY .

2040.
HENRY LEEKS , was again indicted
for stealing 30 pieces of pasteboard, value 2s.; the goods of
the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway Company, his masters.

(MR. HUDDLESTON offered no evidence.)
NOT GUILTY .

2041.
JAMES PERKINS , was indicted
for a robbery on
Robert Barnett, and putting him in fear, and stealing 1 purse, 1 penny, 2 shillings, 2 six
pences, and 1 halfpenny; his property.

MR. BALLANTINE conducted the Prosecution. ROBERT BARNETT. I live in Union-street, in the Borough, on 1st Oct., between three and four o'clock in the morning, I went home with my wife in a cab—I knocked at the door, and took out my purse to pay the cabman; the prisoner came by while I was paying, and shoved himslef between me and the cabman—I said to him, "We will have the pavement made wider for you, young man"—that was all I said, he immediately came back, and struck me in the face, and knocked me down; then a bit of a bother occurred—he and I had a struggle together, and during that time I lost my purse—I had it in my hand—it was hanging down, and I missed it all at once—I do not know who took it, the policeman came up—I gave the
prisoner in custody for the assault—the inspector found my purse on the prisoner at the station, in my presence.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. When you lost your purse you looked for it on the ground? A. Yes; I presumed I had dropped it—I could not find it—the policeman came up while the bother was—the purse was found at the station-house sticking out at the prisoner's collar, he had got his coat buttoned up, and the purse hung out between the button holes, any one might see it—the prisoner was in liquor.

FREDERICK BAKER . I am an inspector of police—the prisoner was brought to the station, which is a quarter of a mile from the spot where this occurred—I observed this purse sticking from the breast of his coat—I think it could not have got there during the struggle, because the part the money was in, was under the coat—his coat was similar to what he has on now, but it was not buttoned up quite so high—the prisoner said he knew nothing at all how it came there.
ROBERT BARNETT (re-examined). When he struck me I put out my hand to defend myself as well as I could—I did not see him make any attempt to rob me.

JOSHUA GOLDING (policeman, M 87). The cries of the children brought me to the place, when I went the prisoner and prosecutor were both on the ground, not one over the other—the prosecutor charged the prisoner with assaulting him—I took the prisoner, and immediately the prosecutor said he had lost his purse—he looked on the ground for it with a candle—I saw the inspector find the purse—I had not seen it before—I had searched the prisoner's pockets, but I had not a light.

WILLIAM BEAZLEY . I am a cabman, the prosecutor hired me from the stand that morning to take him home, saying his wife was very bad—I took him home to the door, and he was paying me the money, he was asking me for a sixpence—the prisoner came along and shoved against him—one word brought up another—one asked the other if he could fight, and away they went at it—they were both down, and rolled over two or three times, and when the prosecutor was at the bottom, the other man hit him—the prosecutor said that man bad hit him—the policeman catched him off the prosecutor—the prosecutor came to me, and said, "I have dropped my purse, I wish you would look for it;" which I did with a light, I could not find it—they got to the station, and came and fetched me.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you ever been in trouble? A. I have had summonses connected with the ordinary business of cab-driving—I have not been in any other trouble—I have never been charged with stealing—I drive a good deal of valuable property—I do not know whether you call it stealing—I carried the job, I will not deny—I was to be bailed out, but I could not get the bail—it was no robbery on my side, the job the things belonged to was a robbery—I was coming by and was called, and carried the job—I had been to Greenwich, and took up this job at the Broadway, Deptford—I took the people to the place I was ordered, and put them down—I do not know whether they escaped.

COURT. Q. Were you not charged with having stolen goods in your possession, and facilitating the escape of the persons? A. That was the charge, I believe—I was not to know whether it was stolen.
NOT GUILTY .

2042.
LOUISA STAINES
, stealing 1 mantle, value 4s.; the goods of
Mary Ann Smith, from her person.

MARY ANN SMITH . On Saturday, 20th Oct., I was at Wandsworth—I saw the prisoner there—I went with her and a young man to have something to drink, at the Rose and Crown—the prisoner took a black mantle from off my shoulders—she doubled her fist, and swore how she would use me if I came near her—I got a policeman, and went with him to a house in a court, and gave the prisoner in charge—the mantle has not been found.
Prisoner. I did not have it; there was some navigator chap with her, who did not pay her—I was asleep when the policeman came with her—I had not had it.

THOMAS DALEY (police-sergeant, V 33). About one o'clock in the morning of Sunday, 21st Oct., I saw the prosecutrix, and she directed me to a court near the water side—I found the prisoner in bed in a room—she said, "She knew nothing about it"—I searched the house but found nothing—I had heard the prosecutrix cry "Police!" three times before I arrived—she had nothing on her shoulders, and it was a very damp night—she told me what had happened, and told me the prisoner's name—I found the prisoner in bed, half an hour afterwards—two prostitutes and a known thief live in the next house to where I found her.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

2043. In the case of
JAMES WESTON
, indicted for the wilful murder of
Maria Weston and
Maria Elizabeth Weston, the
JURY,
upon the evidence of Gilbert M'Murdo, Esq., surgeon of the gaol, found the prisoner to be insane, and not in a fit state to plead to the indictment.
ORDERED TO BE DETAINED until Her Majesty's pleasure be known.

div0.p: For the case of FREDERICK GEORGE MANNING and MARIA MANNING, see page 654.

div1.p:
2044.
STEPHEN ALFRED JORDAN, alias Dowland
, feloniously assaulting
Sarah Frances Ewings, on 19th Sept., and stabbing, cutting, and wounding her upon the fore part of her throat, with intent to murder her.

SARAH FRANCES EWINGS . I am a single woman. In Sept. last I was residing in Francis-street, Newington—I have known the prisoner fifteen months—during that period I have been on terms of intimacy with him—I am now in the family way by him—he came to see me at the lodging in Francis-street—I went to lodge there on 25th July—on Sunday evening, 16th Sept., I wrote a letter to the prisoner, and posted it on Monday morning.

THOMAS PRITCHARD (policeman, P 22). On Monday last, the 22nd, I served a notice on the prisoner to produce certain letters, of which this is a copy—(This was a notice to produce the letter of the prosecutrix, of 17th Sept., and also a letter of the prisoner's to her, requesting her to meet him at Brixton Church. The prisoner was here asked to produce the prosecutrix's letter; he said, "I have not got it."

SARAH FRANCES EWINOS
re-examined. The substance of my letter was to tell him that I had left my friends for his sake, and as I had not heard from him for a fortnight I should write to my grandmother, and inform her that I had found out that he was deceiving me, and if I did not hear from him by Thursday morning, the letter would be posted to grandmother—I knew where he resided then—on Wednesday 19th I received a letter from

him at nine o'clock in the morning—I took that letter back to him on the Wednesday evening, to Brixton Church—(The prisoner on being asked to pro
duce this letter said, "I have not got it.")—the substance of that letter was to meet him at" Brixton Church, at eight o'clock to-morrow night; don't come if you don't bring this letter with you; I am going to take you to Croydon; don't tell Mrs. Chapman where you are going; "that was the landlady where I lodged—it said twice," Don't come if you don't bring this letter with you "I went in consequence to Brixton Church that evening, as I was not certain which night be meant—the note was dated 17th; I thought he bad made a mistake, and meant the 18th, as he posted it on the Tuesday—when I got to Brixton Church, it was eight o'clock—I met him there—he asked me how I was; and then he said, "Have you brought the letter?"—I said, "Yes; "and he said, "I have taken a lodging for you at Croydon"—I afterwards gave him the letter—he said, "I have brought paper and ink, and now you must write to Mrs. Chapman to tell her that she will hear from you in a day or two; "and I was to write a letter to him at the same time, in case my friends should inquire anything—I wrote the two letters under a lamp-post, at Brixton Church, and gave them to him—he brought the paper, pen, and ink with him, and I wrote on the cover of a book which he brought with the paper—after I gave him the letters we went towards Dulwich—I did not know the way myself—he told me he was going to take me to Penge-common to take the train for Croydon—I asked him what I was to do without clothes—he said I should return in a day or two for them—as we were walking along, he asked me how I came to send him such a threatening letter; did I mean it—I said, "No, I did not mean it, and he was not to think anything more about it; I only did it to frighten him"—as we went along we came to a wood, which the prisoner said was Dulwich-wood; we got over a stile which led into it—before we came to the stile he told me I was not to be frightened if I heard a rustling among the bushes, as there were rabbits that ran about there—there was a path through the wood, with bushes on each side—there was not room for us to walk together, and I went first—when we first got into the wood, I said to the prisoner, "You had better go first, as you know the way better;" and he then went first—he had hold of my hand at the time—we stopped three times—I asked him what he was stopping for—he said he thought he heard some one coming; perhaps it was the game-keeper—it was dark—as we went along he put his arm round my neck twice; and kissed me, and the third time he put his arm round my neck, kissed me and stuck a razor in my throat—he then threw me on the ground, and knelt on my side, put his two fingers in my throat, and held me down—I succeeded in getting his hand away, and got upon my knees—he then knocked me down again with a pistol, held me down, and beat me and struck me about the forehead with the pistol, first with the handle, and then with the other part—I got upon my knees again, and he took the razor and tried to cut roe at the right side of my neck—he knocked me down again, and I got hold of the razor blade with my right hand; it was in bis right hand—I got upon my knees again as I held it, and he knelt on my breast, put his hand on the back of my head, and tried to get the razor from out of my hand as he held me down—I then broke the razor, and he beat me and knocked me on the head again, and then he went away, and I got up—the first cut was in front of my throat—when I got up he was gone—after I had broken the razor, I felt him try to cut me at the back of my neck with something sharp—he went away directly—I did not see him go—when I got up I was

bleeding, and found my throat was cut—I went to a cottage a short distance off—a person from the cottage took me to Mr. Ray, the surgeon, at Dulwich—the prisoner did not make any observation to me from the time he first attacked me till he left me—I tried to say, "Oh, you wretch!" but be held me, and prevented me speaking—up to 25th July I had been in service, and left to go away from my friends that they should not know—on 2d July the pri
soner told me to go to the Registry-office to give three weeks notice, and then we could be married on the day I left my situation—it was in consequence of that, that I left my situation—on the day I left my situation, I went to Mr. Fraser's chapel—the night before the prisoner had agreed to meet me there, at nine o'clock.
COURT. Q. Did he come? A. No; I was at that time pregnant—I had communicated that to him in June.
Prisoner. I know nothing about her going to the registrar; I have no question to ask her.

WILLIAM HUNT . I reside on Dulwich-common, about fifty yards from Dulwich-wood. On Wednesday night, 19th Sept., about a quarter to ten, I heard a noise in the road—my wife opened the door—I went and saw a female there, who turned out to be the prosecutrix—her face and hands were completely covered with blood, and her hair hanging all down the sides of her face and neck—my children cried with alarm at the spectacle she pre
sented, and, from some impression I had at the time, I put her outside—I afterwards went out with a light, and found her in the road—she had her dress clenched up in her hand, and tucked in her throat—in consequence of a complaint she made to me, 1 took her to Mr. Ray, a surgeon in the neigh
bourhood—after I had done that, in consequence of what she said, I went into the wood with Wood the constable—he walked before me and picked up a bonnet, a fur Victorine, a fur cape, a black shawl, two white pocket-handkerchiefs, the white handle of a razor, and a bottle of blue ink—they were in the wood, about 360 yards from the stile where you enter the wood—I observed finger-marks of blood on the stile.

JOHN WOOD (policeman P 131). On the night of 19th Sept., I accom
panied Hunt to Dulwich-wood—I went over the stile, and at some distance from it I found a fur Victorine, a pocket-handkerchief, a small bottle of blue ink, a green drawn silk bonnet, a black crape shawl, and a razor handle—the blade was picked up by Jefferys about three feet off, among some leaves and grass near the footpath—I saw him pick it up—it was about three feet from where we found the other things—they were all together saturated with blood, and there was a great quantity of blood in the footpath—it was not above a foot wide—there was a great quantity of blood on the bushes and oak leaves.
JOHN JEFFERY (policeman, P 303). I accompanied last witness and Hunt to Dulwich-wood, on 19th Sept., between twelve and oue o'clock—I found the razor produced.

THOMAS PRITCHARD (policeman, P 22). On 19th Sept., I was acting as inspector at the Camberwell police-station. About one o'clock in the morn
ing the prosecutrix was brought there by Mr. Ray, the surgeon—in conse
quence of what she stated I went to 3, St. Ann's-road, Brixton, about three in the morning, and found the prisoner there in bed—when I went into the room he spoke first, and said, "It is all right; I know what you have come about"—I then said, "Were you at Dulwich last night?"—he said he was—I then desired him to get up and dress himself—he did so—I told him he was charged with attempting to murder a female in Dulwich-wood—he said, "Say no more about it"—I examined a coat I found there, and found this barrel of

a pistol in the breast-pocket—the prisoner said it was loaded with ball and powder—I examined it afterwards, and found it was loaded with ball and powder—the right sleeve of the coat had blood upon it, and there were small damp spots of blood on the breast—I noticed his shirt, and there were spots of blood on the front near the collar and on the waistbands—I took him to the station.

Prisoner. Q. Did I speak to you or the landlady? A. To me—she went into the room first, but I was close to her—she opened the door and asked if Stephen was at home—some one answered, but I did not hear the answer—the door was on the jar, and I was close behind her on the top of the stairs—there was another man sleeping in the room—you said the coat was yours—I saw it lying on the floor.

JOHN PLOWMAN . I live at 3, St. Ann's-road, Brixton, and know the prisoner—he lived at that house in Sept., and had done so about eighteen months—I saw him there on 19th Sept.—the razor produced is mine—about four o'clock in the afternoon of that day, I laid it up on the shelf in the room where I shaved with it—on that afternoon I saw the prisoner with a pistol in his hand—he gave it me to go and shoot it off—I said, "I would not, it was loaded too heavy;" and he took it and fired it off himself, and broke the stock off—this is the same pistol.
Prisoner, Q. Did you ever see the pistol afterwards? A. No; I left the razor in the washhouse, on a shelf at the side of the fire-place.

EDWARD RAY . I am a surgeon at Dulwich. On the night of 19th Sept., the prosecutrix was brought to me by Hunt—her head, face, neck, hands, and client, were covered with blood—I found the head and face extensively bruised, and several small contused wounds on the scalp—they were such injuries as might be inflicted by a blunt instrument—they might have been produced by the handle of a pistol—from the appearance the blows were very violent—there was a deep gash in the front part of her throat, about three or four inches long, which penetrated the windpipe just below the root of the tongue, and through this wound she was breathing—on the right side of the neck there was another wound of the same extent, but only penetrating the skin—they were such wounds as would be inflicted by a cutting instrument, and might have been produced by this razor—on her hands I found several wounds, one of them laying open the joint at the root of the forefinger of the left-hand—they were such injuries as might have been caused by her grasping a sharp instrument—there were wounds on both hands—the wound on the neck, and the bruises on the head were likely to prove fatal—I had her con
veyed to the hospital, after doing what was necessary.

CHARLES SAUNDERS . I am a medical student, at Guy's Hospital. The prosecutrix was brought there on 20th Sept., and 1 attended to her under, Mr. Bransby Cooper's directions, for some time—I considered her life was in danger until the wounds had closed—that was about three weeks or a month. Prisoner's Defence. I did not tell her to go to the Registrar's-office at all; she showed me a paper on the evening of Wednesday, 25th, and tried to persuade me to go home with her to her lodging; I did not go till the 28th, Saturday night; and I went once or twice after that, perhaps three or four times, and when 1 found out in what state she was I had no more to do with her; I knew it could not be by me, as that was the first improper connection I had with her, on 28th July; when she found I had left her, she constantly kept sending threatening letters to me, saying she would go home to her friends and say it was me that was the cause of it, and that was the cause of a quarrel whenever we met; I did not get her to write any letters that night; that is all I have to say.
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
DEATH .

2045.
HANNAH DREWETT
, feloniously stabbing and wounding
Emma Bolton on the left arm and nose, with intent to maim and disable her.

MR. MELLER conducted the Prosecution.
EMMA BOLTON . I live at 10, New-street, New Kent-road; I know the prisoner as a neighbour, she lived next door but one to me. On Thursday evening, 18th Oct., about half-past nine o'clock, I went to her house to borrow a jug—I knocked at the door, she opened it—I told her I wanted her to lend me a jug—she began to make use of very improper language, and said she would beat my bbrains out—she accused me of stealing a key—I said I had not seen it—she then called me a bwh, and struck me twice on the arm with a poker, and told me to go out—I was in the pas
sage—she went into her room to get the poker—as I was going out of the house she came after me and stabbed me three times with a knife on the arm and nose, and I fell senseless into a young woman's arms—I had not offered to strike her or given her any provocation—I was taken to a surgeon.

Prisoner. You were in my room when I hit you with the knife; I was cutting a piece of wood, and you were coming to strike me; it was dark, and I cannot say where the knife cut you; I own I hit you with the poker, after asking you ten or a dozen times to go out of my room, which you refused to do. Witness. I never entered the room, I went no further than the passage—I did not see her cutting any wood.

MARTHA WOODWARD . I am the prosecutrix's mother, and the wife of Charles Woodward, an ironmonger, of 10, New-street. I came home that night, and hearing my daughter at the prisoner's door asking for the loan of a jug, I came out with a jug in my hand—I heard the prisoner say, "Stand back," and call her a b—wh—I then saw her strike my daughter, with what I thought was a stick, three times across the arm—I saw my daughter come out of the passage and the prisoner after her with a knife in her hand, which she jobbed three or four times against my daughter—I ran to her assistance—she was covered with blood—the prisoner called me a b—cow, and said she would stick me with the bknife through my b—heart—she then went in-doors, and I took my daughter to a surgeon.

WILLIAM HENRY DRY . I am a surgeon. The prisoner was brought to me on Thursday evening, 18th Oct.—I found a fracture of the left arm, about two and a half inches above the wrist—I also found an incised wound about two inches above the elbow joint, about an inch and a half in extent, and an incised wound on the face and left side of the nose—on examining her next morning she called my attention to an incised wound in the chest of about an inch—the incised wounds were superficial, dividing veins but not arteries—there had been considerable effusion of blood—she is under my care now—the fracture might have been produced by a blow with a poker—it must have required considerable force. JOHN THOROUGHGOOD (policeman, P 180). I took the prisoner, and told her what she was charged with—she said she had no business in her room—while she paid her rent no one should come into her room—she had in her hand part of the handle of a knife—I searched, and found this blade of a dinner-knife in her apartment (produced)—I found this poker in the fire-place—the prisoner had been drinking, but was quite conscious of what she was doing—I found part of the handle of a knife near the front door, near where the prosecutrix says she was stabbed—I did not see any wood in the room.

(The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was read, as follows: "I have got no more to say than that she came into my room, and burst my door open frequently, and took my key away last evening.")

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2046.
WILLIAM KNIGHT
, embezzling 3l. 5s. 10d., of
Henry Bradforth, his master; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2047.
SOPHIA NEAL
, stealing 2 shirts, value 3s.; the goods of
James Charles Tinsley; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2048.
JAMES HEALEY
, stealing 8 lbs. weight of lead, value 8s.; the goods of
Lewis Ash, his master: to which he pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

2049. In the case of
HENRY WATSON
, indicted for the wilful murder of,
Louisa Charlotte Watson,
the Jury, on the evidence of Mr. M'Murdo, surgeon of the gaol, found that the prisoner was of unsound mind, and not in a fit state to take his trial.

2050.
GEORGE BRISTOW
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Myers, and stealing 1 tippet, and 1 shirt, value 3s. 6d.; his pro
perty: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2051.
JOHN PURNELL was indicted
for bigamy.

JANE JONES . I am single, and reside at Langford, Somersetshire. I know the prisoner and Mary Parsons—she is my cousin—I was present when they were married—I believe it was four years ago, but I am not quite sure about the date—I have no doubt the prisoner is the person—I believe the marriage was at St. John's Church, Bristol, but I am not sure.

PHÅ’BE SOPHIA LIGHT . I am a widow, and reside at Clifton. I remember Mary Parsons being married in 1845, to a person named Purnell—the prisoner is that person, they returned after the wedding to my house to breakfast—I saw Mary Parsons last week.

MARY ELIZABETH LUCAS . I resided at Tylehurst. I was married in June, 1849, to the prisoner, in the name of James Richardson, at Christ Church, Surrey—I believed at the time he was a single man; he told me so.

Prisoner. Q. In what name were we lodging at the time of our marriage? A. In the name of Smith; I first became acquainted with you, I believe, in Nov., 1848, or a little before that; I did not know you were married till after I married you; I came to your house twice on business; I did not then see a person who I believed was Mrs. Purnell; I saw a person who you denied was Mrs. Purnell; you were living with her as a wife, and had got one child by her; I agreed to stand godmother for that child.

COURT. Q. Did you live with the prisoner before you married him? A. Yes; a short time, not longer than a month; we lived in the name of Mr. and Mrs. Smith—that was under a promise of marriage—I did not know the woman 1 saw was his wife.

ALFRED AYLETTE (policeman). I produce two certificates; the first is of a marriage in 1845, at St. James', Bristol, on 22d Sept., between John Pur
nell

and Mary Parsons, and the second of a marriage at Christ Church, Surrey, on 12th June, 1849, between James Richardson and Mary Elizabeth Lucas—I have compared them with the originals myself, and find them to be true copies.

Prisoner's Defence. Lucas knew I was married; she has several times drank tea with me and my wife; about a week before we left Reading, to live together as man and wife in London, she gave me 5l. for the purpose of send
ing my wife home on a visit, that she might be absent, and I have a letter of hers which proves she was fully aware I was married—(the witness, Lucas, stating that this letter was her writing, the prisoner read it—it commenced, "Miss Lucas will not be able to call on Mrs. Purnell this afternoon, in con
sequence of the dampness of the weather, &c. &c.")—after she had lived with me two months, she became anxious of satisfying her friends that she was not living in a state of prostitution, but was a married woman; she became desirous of having a certificate to send to her friends; she said nothing could be done to prosecute me without her, and the least I could do, was to give her the opportunity of satisfying them, and I married her in the name of Richardson.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Two Months.

2052.
JOSIAH WILLIAM CHARLTON was indicted
for bigamy.

ALICE MATTHEWS . I am the wife of Richard Matthews. I was present at Marston Church, on 29th May, 1845, when the prisoner was married to Susannah Hale—I knew the prisoner before—I saw Susannah down below, about ten minutes ago.
Prisoner. Q. Was I sober at the time? A. No; very tipsy.

ALFRED WAKEFIELD (policeman). I produce two certificates, one I got from Waterloo Church, Lambeth, and the—other from the Parish Church of Marston, near Oxford—I compared them with the original; they are correct copies (read)—I took the prisoner in custody at the Elephant and Castle, and on the way to the station he asked me what I took him for—I told him, and he asked who the female was, walking on a-head—I said I did not know—he said,"That is my wife, I believe"—I said I did not know her—we passed her, and he said, "That is my wife"—I said, "Your married wife?"—he said, "Yes;" and said he had been married twice—I have seen the same woman here to-day.
Prisoner. I said I had some knowledge of her, but I did not acknowledge her to be my wife.
MARY ELIZABETH KNEBB . I am single—I was present at Waterloo Church last Christmas day, and saw the prisoner married to Sarah Harriett Perkins.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not aware what I was about at the time of my first marriage; I was intoxicated.

ALICE MATTHEWS
re-examined. He was very tipsy—he walked to Church, but could hardly walk home—as soon as he came out of Church he went to bed, and did not get up till the next morning—he lived with his wife after
wards, and had some children.

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2053.
HENRY JOHNSON
, stealing 1 cheese, value 18s.; the goods of
William Carter: having been before convicted.
MR. COCKLE conducted the Prosecution. WILLIAM BROWN. I am shopman to William Carter, of 28, Bedford-row,

Walworth. On 22d Sept., I saw the prisoner pass the window with some cheese in a basket—I ran after him, he turned round, and when he saw me he dropped the cheese and ran away—I ran after him and caught him—he said, "Let me go, let me go, I did not mean to do it"—the cheese weighed 28lbs., and was worth 18s.—I had seen it safe in our shop-window half an hour before, partly in and partly out—I was serving customers in the shop, and did not see what was going on outside—any one outside could get hold of the cheese and pull it under the window—I missed it before I left the shop—I did not lose sight of the prisoner.
JOHN TRAFFORD (policeman, P 175). I received the prisoner in charge from Brown—he said starvation would drive a man to anything.
Prisoner's Defence. It is my first offence.
WILLIAM ROMAIN (policeman, L 38). I produce a certificate (read—Henry Francis, convicted March, 1849, and confined six months)—I was present—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY .** Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2054.
WILLIAM ANDREWS and
JOHN DOUGLAS
, stealing 1 skewer, value 3s.; the goods of
Dame Isabella Cooper.

MR. MEW conducted the Prosecution. THOMAS HONEYBOND. I am a watch-maker and silversmith at Brentford. Some time in Sept., Douglas came and offered me for sale a broken silver skewer, which bad a crest upon it—I said it looked suspicious, and asked how he came by it—he said he found it in the dust—he did not say where—he said be worked for Mr. Weston, the dust-contractor—I told him he must leave it and inquiry must be made, and he must call again in a few days—he said he had no objection—I gave the skewer to the police—Douglas called again, and I told him I had given it to the police, and my orders were to give him into custody—he went out of the shop and spoke to a man outside, who I believe was Andrews, but I cannot swear to him—these are the pieces of the skewer (produced).

HENRY UPTON (policeman, V 44). I received information from Mr. Honeybond, and he gave me this skewer, and a description of the parties—I took the two prisoners into custody—Andrews said, "I had the skewer, but I did not offer it for sale"—he said Douglas did.

HANNAH ELLIS . I am cook to Lady Isabella Cooper, of Isleworth—she is a widow, and was so when I went to live with her six years ago—this broken skewer is hers, and has her crest on—this one (producing another) is one now in use—I have known Andrews about four months—he used to come to Lady Cooper's for orders for Mr. Waterman, the poulterer—he used to come to the kitchen where the skewers lay about.
Cross-examined by MR. WOOLLETT. Q. What establishment has Lady Cooper? A. About sixteen servants—I never saw Andrews come inside the kitchen-door—a great many tradespeople come to the house.
GEORGE HIGGINS . I am butler to Lady Cooper. I know these parts of a skewer—when the policeman came I missed such a one.
Douglas's Defence. Andrews told me he found it a fortnight before, stuck in the ground.

(Andrews received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

2055.
ANN GRAY
, stealing 3 smock-frocks and 1 teapot, value 5s.; the goods of
Thomas Samuel Nellyer; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2056.
RICHARD KNAPP
, embezzling 4s. 8d., 2s. 6d., and 2s. 3d.; the moneys of
James Vaston Baynes: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

2057.
WILLIAM EVE
, embezzling 6d.; the goods of
George Hayward, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

2058.
JAMES ISAAC TUPPER
, feloniously stabbing
Sarah Tupper on her left breast, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

MR. PLATT conducted the Prosecution.
SARAH TUPPER . The prisoner is my husband—we have been married twenty-five years, and lived in Grange-walk, Bermondsey—when in liquor his conduct is bad—it is not so bad when he is in his solid senses. On 19th Oct. we had been out walking, we returned about nine o'clock and met my daughter and her sweetheart at the door—my husband was very tipsy—he was angry with my daughter and the young man, and they went out—I was rather obstinate, and insisted on letting them in again—I had had a drop of drink as well as him—I called him a bad father—he was mending a pen, and jumped up to hinder me opening the door—I was very obstinate—he went to shut the door, and I felt the knife come into my right breast, and recollect nothing else.

Prisoner. Did you not go out with your daughter, and come in and vio
lently attack me? A. No.

THOMAS MASON (policeman, M 259). I was called into the next house and found a doctor dressing the wound—I went next door, and the prisoner opened the door and came out to me and said, "I am the man; is she dead?"—he said, "Then I am sorry for it"—he had been drinking, but was sensible in his speech—I asked for the knife—he gave me this knife (produced).
Prisoner. Q. Did not I say I was very sorry for what had happened? A. You said you were sorry to think she was not dead.

WILLIAM FALL TURNER . I am a medical man. I was called, and found the prosecutrix fainting with a punctured wound on her right breast, about two-thirds of an inch in extent and two inches deep—a knife like this would produce it—I attended her ten days—she has quite recovered now.

Prisoner's Defence. She had followed me all day and pelted me with stones and brickbats; I was as sober as I am now, and busily engaged writing, with the knife in my hand; she bounced from the sofa and struck me on the face; I never rose a hand against her; I am strong enough, if I wished to take advantage of her, without using a knife; it was easy for the policeman to be mistaken in what I said.
NOT GUILTY .

2059.
THOMAS CONOLLY and
WILLIAM REECE were indicted for
feloniously stabbing
James Christopher Brockwell in the back, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JAMES CHRISTOPHER BROCKWELL . I am a waterman, of Dock-gate. On 17th Oct., about one o'clock, I was in Tooley-street, and heard a cry of "Murder) "in Morgan's-lane—I ran down, and saw the prisoners—Conolly up with a knife and stabbed me in the back as soon as I got there, and Reece said, "Give it to him again"—I was taken to the hospital—I had not said or done anything to them.

PERCIVAL PALMER. I am a waterman of Horsleydown—I was in Tooley-street, and saw the prisoners arm-in-arm—as soon as I met them Reece struck me and knocked me down—I called "Murder!" seeing Conolly with a knife—Brockwell came up, but had not spoken a word or done anything, before Conolly stabbed him in the back—Reece said, "Give it him again"—a policeman came and took them.

Reece. Q. Did I strike you? A. Yes first, in the back of the neck—I did not pretend to be drunk—I did not follow you till I was kicked—Brock-well said, "I feel some blood running down my back, I think I am stabbed"—it was after that Reece said, "Give it him again."

HENRY HUNT (policeman, M 82). I heard a cry of" Murder! "and went to Morgan's-lane—Palmer and Brockwell spoke to me—the prisoners were not there then—Palmer afterwards pointed out Conolly to me on a vessel at Griffins's wharf, and said he was the man that stabbed him—Conolly pulled the knife out of a sheath round his waist, and said, "Yes, I am the boy, and this is the knife that done it: I done all I could for to do for him"—he repeated that more than once or twice on the way to the station—he had been drinking, but was perfectly sensible, and could walk well—it was about one o'clock in the morning.

WILLIAM SOP (policeman, M 162). I heard a cry of" Murder! "near where I saw Brockwell, supported by two men; blood was running from his back—Palmer went with me on board a ship at Griffin's Wharf, and pointed out Reece, who said, "Yes, I was there, I will go with you."

FREDERICK HEZEKIAH HARTSHORN . I am assistant-surgeon at Guy's. On 17th Oct. Brock well was brought there—I found an incised wound on the right side of his spine, an inch and a half long and two inches deep—this knife would produce it—it was not dangerous of itself, but if it had penetrated directly, instead of obliquely, it would have penetrated the lungs—he con
tinued there till last Monday, and is still an out-patient.

Conolly's Defence. Palmer staggered against Reece, pretending to be drunk, and struck him twice; I said, "Come and strike me, and I will give it you again; "he struck me three or four times; I struck him, and he

sung out for two men, who followed us, and called," Knife the br! knife him!" I then drew my sheath-knife, and told Palmer if he came near I would give him the knife; he came to strike me, and in throwing off the blow this happened—what was done it was I that did it, Reece was not near.

CONOLLY—
GUILTY .—
Transported for Ten Years.

REECE—
GUILTY
of an Assault:
Confined Twelve Months.

2060.
CHARLES MOORE
, unlawfully obtaining goods by false pretences.

JOHN COLLETT BONUS . I a man ironmonger, of Warrington-place, Wands
worth—the prisoner has had goods of me for Mr. Forster, of the Three Goats, who has paid for them; the last time was ten or twelve months ago—he came to me on 14th July, and asked for some bolts and screws for Mr. Forster—I let him have them, supposing he was sent by Mr. Forster—I after
wards saw the prisoner at Mr. Forster's, and asked him how he could think of coming to me and getting goods when he was not sent—he said, "I know I have done wrong; I will pay you."

GEORGE FORSTER . I keep the Three Goats, Wandsworth-road. I have employed the prisoner occasionally, and sent him to Mr. Bonus for goods in my name—the last time was ten months ago—I have not seen him since.
WILLIAM GIBBS (policeman, V 77). I took the prisoner, he gave me his address; I went there, and found these two cross-bolts (produced).

JOHN C. BONUS
re-examined. I cannot swear to the bolt, but I gave the prisoner such.

GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor, and Jury.—
Confined Three Months.

2061.
JAMES CROKE was indicted
for bigamy.

MARY SHEAN . I saw the prisoner married, more than ten years ago, at Dr. Cotters's house, Shandrum, Ireland, by Father Connell, the clergyman of the parish—I saw the prisoner's wife on 1st May, in the same town where she was married—she went by the name of Croke—he left her and her two chil
dren.

MARY ROURKE . I live in Jeffery's-buildings, Westminster, and have been a widow—I became acquainted with the prisoner about four and a half years ago—he passed as a single man—I got married to him at St. John's, in the Waterloo-road, and have had a child—I had no money.
THOMAS DUKR (policeman). I produce two certificates of marriage, and have seen the registers.
Prisoner's Defence. I wrote to my wife twice, and got no answer; I Left her in 1839, and did not know whether she was dead or alive.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Year.

2062.
GEORGE FOSTER
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles Woolston, and stealing 1 shilling and 2 sixpences; the moneys of
Louisa Gallington: 15 knives, 1 fork, and other articles, value 9s. 6d.; the goods of the said Charles Woolston: having been before con
victed.

JAMES POTTER (policeman, P 227). On 26th Sept., about half-past five in the morning, I was on duty in Stockwell-park-road, and saw the prisoner come out of Mr. Woolston's kitchen-window, which is just level with the ground—I was about fifty yards from him, he looked at me, and then walked away—I followed him half a mile, and then asked him what his business was at the house he had come from; he said it was his master's house, be worked there—I asked him to accompany me back to the house—he did so, and then said, "That is not the house"—I seized him by the arm, he drew this crow-bar (produced) from bis pocket, and attempted to strike me—a brother constable seized his arm—I took him to the station, and found some lucifers on him.
Prisoner. Q. What time did you come up to me? A. At a quarter or twenty minutes to six o'clock, you were out of my sight in turning a corner.

JOHN PALMER SOMERS (policeman). I was with Potter—I found the window open, it opens like a door—I found on it the impression of this crow
bar, and also on the sitting-room door—there is a very peculiar mark on the instrument, which I noticed—this knife-box was on the floor, and articles were strewed all about the place.

LOUISA GALLINGTON . I am servant to Mr. Woolston, and was awoke by the police—I had fastened up the house, but had not put up the inside shutter to the window in question—I and my sister were left alone in the house—I found a knife-box removed from the kitchen to the breakfast parlour; the knives were put into a bag ready to take away.
Prisoners Defence. I am innocent; this tool is what I use in rat-catching.

JOSEPH SKINNER (policeman, P 57). I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's conviction—(read—Convicted April, 1847, and confined twelve months)—I was present—he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Transported for Ten Years.

div0.p:
The judgment upon HORATIO NELSON SPINKS, for rape, tried on 23d Aug., before MR. JUSTICE ERLE, was
Transported for Life.
The following Prisoners, upon whom the Judgment of the Court was respited at the time of trial, have been sentenced as under:

12
Haines, Mary Ann... 256.. Transported for seven years.

13
Bassett, James... 269.. Transported for seven years.

17
Reynolds, Thomas William... 391.. Confined eighteen months.
